return {
  -- Completion engine
  {
    "hrsh7th/nvim-cmp",
    event = "InsertEnter",
    dependencies = {
      "hrsh7th/cmp-nvim-lsp",
      "hrsh7th/cmp-buffer",
      "hrsh7th/cmp-path",
      "saadparwaiz1/cmp_luasnip",
      "L3MON4D3/LuaSnip",
      "rafamadriz/friendly-snippets",
    },
    config = function()
      local cmp = require("cmp")
      local luasnip = require("luasnip")

      -- Load friendly-snippets
      require("luasnip.loaders.from_vscode").lazy_load()

      cmp.setup({
        snippet = {
          expand = function(args)
            luasnip.lsp_expand(args.body)
          end,
        },
        window = {
          completion = cmp.config.window.bordered(),
          documentation = cmp.config.window.bordered(),
        },
        mapping = cmp.mapping.preset.insert({
          ["<C-b>"] = cmp.mapping.scroll_docs(-4),
          ["<C-f>"] = cmp.mapping.scroll_docs(4),
          ["<C-Space>"] = cmp.mapping.complete(),
          ["<C-e>"] = cmp.mapping.abort(),
          ["<CR>"] = cmp.mapping.confirm({ select = true }),
          ["<Tab>"] = cmp.mapping(function(fallback)
            if cmp.visible() then
              cmp.select_next_item()
            elseif luasnip.expand_or_jumpable() then
              luasnip.expand_or_jump()
            else
              fallback()
            end
          end, { "i", "s" }),
          ["<S-Tab>"] = cmp.mapping(function(fallback)
            if cmp.visible() then
              cmp.select_prev_item()
            elseif luasnip.jumpable(-1) then
              luasnip.jump(-1)
            else
              fallback()
            end
          end, { "i", "s" }),
        }),
        sources = cmp.config.sources({
          { name = "nvim_lsp", priority = 1000 },
          { name = "luasnip", priority = 750 },
          { name = "buffer", priority = 500 },
          { name = "path", priority = 250 },
        }),
        formatting = {
          format = function(entry, vim_item)
            local icons = {
              Text = "󰉿",
              Method = "󰆧",
              Function = "󰊕",
              Constructor = "",
              Field = "󰜢",
              Variable = "󰀫",
              Class = "󰠱",
              Interface = "",
              Module = "",
              Property = "󰜢",
              Unit = "󰑭",
              Value = "󰎠",
              Enum = "",
              Keyword = "󰌋",
              Snippet = "",
              Color = "󰏘",
              File = "󰈙",
              Reference = "󰈇",
              Folder = "󰉋",
              EnumMember = "",
              Constant = "󰏿",
              Struct = "󰙅",
              Event = "",
              Operator = "󰆕",
              TypeParameter = "",
            }
            vim_item.kind = string.format("%s %s", icons[vim_item.kind] or "", vim_item.kind)
            vim_item.menu = ({
              nvim_lsp = "[LSP]",
              luasnip = "[Snip]",
              buffer = "[Buf]",
              path = "[Path]",
            })[entry.source.name]
            return vim_item
          end,
        },
        experimental = {
          ghost_text = true,
        },
      })
    end,
  },

  -- Snippet engine
  {
    "L3MON4D3/LuaSnip",
    lazy = true,
    dependencies = {
      "rafamadriz/friendly-snippets",
    },
  },
}

file.content:
local map = vim.keymap.set

-- ESC alternative
map("i", "jk", "<ESC>", { desc = "Exit insert mode" })

-- Window navigation
map("n", "<C-h>", "<C-w>h", { desc = "Go to left window" })
map("n", "<C-j>", "<C-w>j", { desc = "Go to lower window" })
map("n", "<C-k>", "<C-w>k", { desc = "Go to upper window" })
map("n", "<C-l>", "<C-w>l", { desc = "Go to right window" })

-- Window resize
map("n", "<C-Up>", "<cmd>resize +2<cr>", { desc = "Increase window height" })
map("n", "<C-Down>", "<cmd>resize -2<cr>", { desc = "Decrease window height" })
map("n", "<C-Left>", "<cmd>vertical resize -2<cr>", { desc = "Decrease window width" })
map("n", "<C-Right>", "<cmd>vertical resize +2<cr>", { desc = "Increase window width" })

-- Buffer navigation
map("n", "<Tab>", "<cmd>bnext<cr>", { desc = "Next buffer" })
map("n", "<S-Tab>", "<cmd>bprevious<cr>", { desc = "Previous buffer" })
map("n", "<leader>bd", "<cmd>bdelete<cr>", { desc = "Delete buffer" })
map("n", "<leader>bD", "<cmd>bdelete!<cr>", { desc = "Force delete buffer" })

-- Clear search highlight
map("n", "<leader>h", "<cmd>nohlsearch<cr>", { desc = "Clear search highlight" })

-- Save and quit
map("n", "<leader>w", "<cmd>w<cr>", { desc = "Save file" })
map("n", "<leader>W", "<cmd>wa<cr>", { desc = "Save all files" })
map("n", "<leader>q", "<cmd>q<cr>", { desc = "Quit" })
map("n", "<leader>Q", "<cmd>qa<cr>", { desc = "Quit all" })

-- Better indenting (stay in visual mode)
map("v", "<", "<gv", { desc = "Indent left" })
map("v", ">", ">gv", { desc = "Indent right" })

-- Move lines
map("n", "<A-j>", "<cmd>m .+1<cr>==", { desc = "Move line down" })
map("n", "<A-k>", "<cmd>m .-2<cr>==", { desc = "Move line up" })
map("i", "<A-j>", "<esc><cmd>m .+1<cr>==gi", { desc = "Move line down" })
map("i", "<A-k>", "<esc><cmd>m .-2<cr>==gi", { desc = "Move line up" })
map("v", "<A-j>", ":m '>+1<cr>gv=gv", { desc = "Move selection down" })
map("v", "<A-k>", ":m '<-2<cr>gv=gv", { desc = "Move selection up" })

-- Better paste (don't yank replaced text)
map("v", "p", '"_dP', { desc = "Paste without yanking" })

-- Select all
map("n", "<C-a>", "gg<S-v>G", { desc = "Select all" })

-- Split window
map("n", "<leader>sv", "<cmd>vsplit<cr>", { desc = "Split vertical" })
map("n", "<leader>sh", "<cmd>split<cr>", { desc = "Split horizontal" })
map("n", "<leader>sc", "<cmd>close<cr>", { desc = "Close split" })

-- Diagnostic navigation
map("n", "[d", vim.diagnostic.goto_prev, { desc = "Go to previous diagnostic" })
map("n", "]d", vim.diagnostic.goto_next, { desc = "Go to next diagnostic" })
map("n", "<leader>d", vim.diagnostic.open_float, { desc = "Show diagnostic" })

1→local function tmux_socket_name()
     2→  local tmux = vim.env.TMUX
     3→  if not tmux or tmux == "" then
     4→    return "default"
     5→  end
     6→
     7→  local parts = vim.split(tmux, ",", { plain = true })
     8→  if #parts == 0 or parts[1] == "" then
     9→    return "default"
    10→  end
    11→
    12→  return parts[1]
    13→end
    14→
    15→local function set_slime_target(pane_id)
    16→  local cfg = {
    17→    socket_name = tmux_socket_name(),
    18→    target_pane = pane_id,
    19→  }
    20→
    21→  vim.g.slime_target = "tmux"
    22→  vim.g.slime_default_config = cfg
    23→  vim.g.slime_dont_ask_default = 1
    24→  vim.g.slime_bracketed_paste = 1
    25→  vim.b.slime_config = cfg
    26→end
    27→
    28→local function list_agent_panes()
    29→  local format = table.concat({
    30→    "#{pane_id}",
    31→    "#{window_name}",
    32→    "#{pane_current_command}",
    33→    "#{@git_wt_branch}",
    34→    "#{pane_current_path}",
    35→  }, "\t")
    36→
    37→  local lines = vim.fn.systemlist({ "tmux", "list-panes", "-a", "-F", format })
    38→  if vim.v.shell_error ~= 0 then
    39→    return nil
    40→  end
    41→
    42→  local panes = {}
    43→  for _, line in ipairs(lines) do
    44→    local parts = vim.split(line, "\t", { plain = true })
    45→    local pane_id = parts[1] or ""
    46→    local window_name = parts[2] or ""
    47→    local command = parts[3] or ""
    48→    local branch = parts[4] or ""
    49→    local path = parts[5] or ""
    50→
    51→    local is_agent = command == "claude" or command == "opencode" or command == "codex"
    52→    if pane_id ~= "" and (is_agent or branch ~= "") then
    53→      local label =
    54→        string.format("%s  %s  [%s]  %s", pane_id, window_name, command, branch ~= "" and branch or path)
    55→      table.insert(panes, {
    56→        pane_id = pane_id,
    57→        label = label,
    58→      })
    59→    end
    60→  end
    61→
    62→  return panes
    63→end
    64→
    65→local function attach_agent_pane()
    66→  local panes = list_agent_panes()
    67→  if not panes then
    68→    vim.notify("tmux pane list failed", vim.log.levels.ERROR)
    69→    return
    70→  end
    71→
    72→  if #panes == 0 then

file.content:
local function tmux_socket_name()
  local tmux = vim.env.TMUX
  if not tmux or tmux == "" then
    return "default"
  end

  local parts = vim.split(tmux, ",", { plain = true })
  if #parts == 0 or parts[1] == "" then
    return "default"
  end

  return parts[1]
end

local function set_slime_target(pane_id)
  local cfg = {
    socket_name = tmux_socket_name(),
    target_pane = pane_id,
  }

  vim.g.slime_target = "tmux"
  vim.g.slime_default_config = cfg
  vim.g.slime_dont_ask_default = 1
  vim.g.slime_bracketed_paste = 1
  vim.b.slime_config = cfg
end

local function list_agent_panes()
  local format = table.concat({
    "#{pane_id}",
    "#{window_name}",
    "#{pane_current_command}",
    "#{@git_wt_branch}",
    "#{pane_current_path}",
  }, "\t")

  local lines = vim.fn.systemlist({ "tmux", "list-panes", "-a", "-F", format })
  if vim.v.shell_error ~= 0 then
    return nil
  end

  local panes = {}
  for _, line in ipairs(lines) do
    local parts = vim.split(line, "\t", { plain = true })
    local pane_id = parts[1] or ""
    local window_name = parts[2] or ""
    local command = parts[3] or ""
    local branch = parts[4] or ""
    local path = parts[5] or ""

    local is_agent = command == "claude" or command == "opencode" or command == "codex"
    if pane_id ~= "" and (is_agent or branch ~= "") then
      local label =
        string.format("%s  %s  [%s]  %s", pane_id, window_name, command, branch ~= "" and branch or path)
      table.insert(panes, {
        pane_id = pane_id,
        label = label,
      })
    end
  end

  return panes
end

local function attach_agent_pane()
  local panes = list_agent_panes()
  if not panes then
    vim.notify("tmux pane list failed", vim.log.levels.ERROR)
    return
  end

  if #panes == 0 then
    vim.notify("No agent pane found. Start one via `wtc`/`wto`/`wtx`.", vim.log.levels.WARN)
    return
  end

  vim.ui.select(panes, {
    prompt = "Attach agent pane:",
    format_item = function(item)
      return item.label
    end,
  }, function(item)
    if not item then
      return
    end

    set_slime_target(item.pane_id)
    vim.notify("Agent pane attached: " .. item.pane_id, vim.log.levels.INFO)
  end)
end

local function send_prompt_input()
  vim.ui.input({ prompt = "Agent prompt> " }, function(input)
    if not input or vim.trim(input) == "" then
      return
    end

    local ok, err = pcall(function()
      vim.fn["slime#send"](input .. "\r")
    end)
    if not ok then
      vim.notify("Prompt send failed: " .. tostring(err), vim.log.levels.ERROR)
    end
  end)
end

return {
  {
    "jpalardy/vim-slime",
    event = "VeryLazy",
    init = function()
      vim.g.slime_no_mappings = 1
      vim.g.slime_target = "tmux"
      vim.g.slime_bracketed_paste = 1
      vim.g.slime_dont_ask_default = 1
      vim.g.slime_default_config = {
        socket_name = tmux_socket_name(),
        target_pane = "{last}",
      }
    end,
    keys = {
      { "<leader>aa", attach_agent_pane, desc = "Agent attach pane" },
      { "<leader>ap", send_prompt_input, desc = "Agent prompt input" },
      { "<leader>ac", "<cmd>SlimeConfig<cr>", desc = "Agent config" },
      { "<leader>al", "<Plug>SlimeLineSend", mode = "n", remap = true, desc = "Agent send line" },
      { "<leader>as", "<Plug>SlimeParagraphSend", mode = "n", remap = true, desc = "Agent send paragraph" },
      { "<leader>as", "<Plug>SlimeRegionSend", mode = "x", remap = true, desc = "Agent send selection" },
    },
  },
}

content.thinking:
Now I understand the user's Neovim setup. They already have:
- vim-slime for sending text to tmux panes (agent.lua)
- No existing AI chat/question plugin

The user wants a lightweight way to ask Claude Haiku about Neovim usage from within Neovim. Let me think about the best approach:

Options:
1. **codecompanion.nvim** - Full-featured AI plugin with chat, inline assistance, etc. Supports Anthropic/Claude. Might be overkill if they just want quick questions.
2. **Custom lua function** - A simple function that takes input, calls the Anthropic API via curl, and shows the result in a floating window. 

Very lightweight.
3. **gp.nvim** - Another AI plugin, supports Claude.

Given they want "lightweight" and "quick", I think the simplest approach is a dedicated plugin. codecompanion.nvim is the most popular and well-maintained option for this. But let me think about what's truly minimal.

Actually, the simplest approach that matches the "lightweight/quick" requirement would be a small custom lua function that prompts for a question, calls the Anthropic API with curl, and displays the result in a floating window or split. That said, handling API calls and JSON parsing adds complexity, so codecompanion.nvim might be the better balance between simplicity and functionality.

Looking at codecompanion.nvim specifically, it has built-in support for Claude Haiku, quick chat via keybinding, system prompts for context like "You are a Neovim expert", and inline questions. But if the user really just wants a minimal `:AskNvim <question>` command, a tiny custom function using curl would be the most stripped-down option.

I'm weighing two approaches: codecompanion.nvim for a full-featured, well-maintained solution, or a custom lua function for maximum minimalism tailored exactly to this use case.

input.prompt:
Research Neovim plugins that can answer questions about Neovim usage by referencing the user's installed plugins, configuration, and documentation. The user wants to quickly ask a lightweight LLM (Claude Haiku) about how to use Neovim, and have it answer based on their actual setup (installed plugins, keymaps, settings).

Requirements:
- Must be able to reference the user's Neovim config and installed plugin docs
- Should integrate with Anthropic Claude (specifically Haiku for speed/cost)
- Quick invocation from within Neovim (keybinding → question → answer)
- Ideally context-aware: knows what plugins the user has, their keymaps, etc.

Research these specific plugins and any alternatives:
1. codecompanion.nvim - does it support feeding local config/docs as context?
2. gp.nvim - can it reference local files as context?
3. minuet-ai.nvim or similar lightweight alternatives
4. Any plugin that specifically indexes Neovim help docs + user config for Q&A
5. neovim-session-manager or similar that provides config-aware AI assistance
6. avante.nvim - does it have a quick Q&A mode?

For each viable option, report:
- Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?
- Can it include installed plugin documentation/help files?
- Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?
- How lightweight is the setup?
- What's the typical interaction flow (keymap → question → answer)?

Also search for any newer or niche plugins (2024-2025) that specifically solve "ask AI about my Neovim setup".

content.content:
1→local function tmux_socket_name()
     2→  local tmux = vim.env.TMUX
     3→  if not tmux or tmux == "" then
     4→    return "default"
     5→  end
     6→
     7→  local parts = vim.split(tmux, ",", { plain = true })
     8→  if #parts == 0 or parts[1] == "" then
     9→    return "default"
    10→  end
    11→
    12→  return parts[1]
    13→end
    14→
    15→local function set_slime_target(pane_id)
    16→  local cfg = {
    17→    socket_name = tmux_socket_name(),
    18→    target_pane = pane_id,
    19→  }
    20→
    21→  vim.g.slime_target = "tmux"
    22→  vim.g.slime_default_config = cfg
    23→  vim.g.slime_dont_ask_default = 1
    24→  vim.g.slime_bracketed_paste = 1
    25→  vim.b.slime_config = cfg
    26→end
    27→
    28→local function list_agent_panes()
    29→  local format = table.concat({
    30→    "#{pane_id}",
    31→    "#{window_name}",
    32→    "#{pane_current_command}",
    33→    "#{@git_wt_branch}",
    34→    "#{pane_current_path}",
    35→  }, "\t")
    36→
    37→  local lines = vim.fn.systemlist({ "tmux", "list-panes", "-a", "-F", format })
    38→  if vim.v.shell_error ~= 0 then
    39→    return nil
    40→  end
    41→
    42→  local panes = {}
    43→  for _, line in ipairs(lines) do
    44→    local parts = vim.split(line, "\t", { plain = true })
    45→    local pane_id = parts[1] or ""
    46→    local window_name = parts[2] or ""
    47→    local command = parts[3] or ""
    48→    local branch = parts[4] or ""
    49→    local path = parts[5] or ""
    50→
    51→    local is_agent = command == "claude" or command == "opencode" or command == "codex"
    52→    if pane_id ~= "" and (is_agent or branch ~= "") then
    53→      local label =
    54→        string.format("%s  %s  [%s]  %s", pane_id, window_name, command, branch ~= "" and branch or path)
    55→      table.insert(panes, {
    56→        pane_id = pane_id,
    57→        label = label,
    58→      })
    59→    end
    60→  end
    61→
    62→  return panes
    63→end
    64→
    65→local function attach_agent_pane()
    66→  local panes = list_agent_panes()
    67→  if not panes then
    68→    vim.notify("tmux pane list failed", vim.log.levels.ERROR)
    69→    return
    70→  end
    71→
    72→  if #panes == 0 then
    73→    vim.notify("No agent pane found. Start one via `wtc`/`wto`/`wtx`.", vim.log.levels.WARN)
    74→    return
    75→  end
    76→
    77→  vim.ui.select(panes, {
    78→    prompt = "Attach agent pane:",
    79→    format_item = function(item)
    80→      return item.label
    81→    end,
    82→  }, function(item)
    83→    if not item then
    84→      return
    85→    end
    86→
    87→    set_slime_target(item.pane_id)
    88→    vim.notify("Agent pane attached: " .. item.pane_id, vim.log.levels.INFO)
    89→  end)
    90→end
    91→
    92→local function send_prompt_input()
    93→  vim.ui.input({ prompt = "Agent prompt> " }, function(input)
    94→    if not input or vim.trim(input) == "" then
    95→      return
    96→    end
    97→
    98→    local ok, err = pcall(function()
    99→      vim.fn["slime#send"](input .. "\r")
   100→    end)
   101→    if not ok then
   102→      vim.notify("Prompt send failed: " .. tostring(err), vim.log.levels.ERROR)
   103→    end
   104→  end)
   105→end
   106→
   107→return {
   108→  {
   109→    "jpalardy/vim-slime",
   110→    event = "VeryLazy",
   111→    init = function()
   112→      vim.g.slime_no_mappings = 1
   113→      vim.g.slime_target = "tmux"
   114→      vim.g.slime_bracketed_paste = 1
   115→      vim.g.slime_dont_ask_default = 1
   116→      vim.g.slime_default_config = {
   117→        socket_name = tmux_socket_name(),
   118→        target_pane = "{last}",
   119→      }
   120→    end,
   121→    keys = {
   122→      { "<leader>aa", attach_agent_pane, desc = "Agent attach pane" },
   123→      { "<leader>ap", send_prompt_input, desc = "Agent prompt input" },
   124→      { "<leader>ac", "<cmd>SlimeConfig<cr>", desc = "Agent config" },
   125→      { "<leader>al", "<Plug>SlimeLineSend", mode = "n", remap = true, desc = "Agent send line" },
   126→      { "<leader>as", "<Plug>SlimeParagraphSend", mode = "n", remap = true, desc = "Agent send paragraph" },
   127→      { "<leader>as", "<Plug>SlimeRegionSend", mode = "x", remap = true, desc = "Agent send selection" },
   128→    },
   129→  },
   130→}
   131→

1→return {
     2→  -- Completion engine
     3→  {
     4→    "hrsh7th/nvim-cmp",
     5→    event = "InsertEnter",
     6→    dependencies = {
     7→      "hrsh7th/cmp-nvim-lsp",
     8→      "hrsh7th/cmp-buffer",
     9→      "hrsh7th/cmp-path",
    10→      "saadparwaiz1/cmp_luasnip",
    11→      "L3MON4D3/LuaSnip",
    12→      "rafamadriz/friendly-snippets",
    13→    },
    14→    config = function()
    15→      local cmp = require("cmp")
    16→      local luasnip = require("luasnip")
    17→
    18→      -- Load friendly-snippets
    19→      require("luasnip.loaders.from_vscode").lazy_load()
    20→
    21→      cmp.setup({
    22→        snippet = {
    23→          expand = function(args)
    24→            luasnip.lsp_expand(args.body)
    25→          end,
    26→        },
    27→        window = {

    29→          documentation = cmp.config.window.bordered(),
    30→        },
    31→        mapping = cmp.mapping.preset.insert({

    34→          ["<C-Space>"] = cmp.mapping.complete(),
    35→          ["<C-e>"] = cmp.mapping.abort(),
    36→          ["<CR>"] = cmp.mapping.confirm({ select = true }),
    37→          ["<Tab>"] = cmp.mapping(function(fallback)
    38→            if cmp.visible() then
    39→              cmp.select_next_item()
    40→            elseif luasnip.expand_or_jumpable() then
    41→              luasnip.expand_or_jump()
    42→            else

    44→            end
    45→          end, { "i", "s" }),
    46→          ["<S-Tab>"] = cmp.mapping(function(fallback)

    49→            elseif luasnip.jumpable(-1) then

    53→            end
    54→          end, { "i", "s" }),

Research Neovim plugins that can answer questions about Neovim usage by referencing the user's installed plugins, configuration, and documentation. The user wants to quickly ask a lightweight LLM (Claude Haiku) about how to use Neovim, and have it answer based on their actual setup (installed plugins, keymaps, settings).

Requirements:
- Must be able to reference the user's Neovim config and installed plugin docs
- Should integrate with Anthropic Claude (specifically Haiku for speed/cost)
- Quick invocation from within Neovim (keybinding → question → answer)
- Ideally context-aware: knows what plugins the user has, their keymaps, etc.

Research these specific plugins and any alternatives:
1. codecompanion.nvim - does it support feeding local config/docs as context?
2. gp.nvim - can it reference local files as context?
3. minuet-ai.nvim or similar lightweight alternatives
4. Any plugin that specifically indexes Neovim help docs + user config for Q&A
5. neovim-session-manager or similar that provides config-aware AI assistance
6. avante.nvim - does it have a quick Q&A mode?

For each viable option, report:
- Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?
- Can it include installed plugin documentation/help files?
- Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?
- How lightweight is the setup?
- What's the typical interaction flow (keymap → question → answer)?

Also search for any newer or niche plugins (2024-2025) that specifically solve "ask AI about my Neovim setup".

content.content:
Web search results for query: "gp.nvim neovim plugin anthropic claude local file context 2025"

Links: [{"title":"Top 4 Claude Neovim Plugins & Integrations for 2025","url":"https://skywork.ai/blog/claude-neovim-plugins-2025/"},{"title":"GitHub - coder/claudecode.nvim: 🧩 Claude Code Neovim IDE Extension","url":"https://github.com/coder/claudecode.nvim"},{"title":"GitHub - greggh/claude-code.nvim: Seamless integration between Claude Code AI assistant and Neovim","url":"https://github.com/greggh/claude-code.nvim"},{"title":"GitHub - Robitx/gp.nvim: Gp.nvim (GPT prompt) Neovim AI plugin: ChatGPT sessions & Instructable text/code operations & Speech to text [OpenAI, Ollama, Anthropic, ..]","url":"https://github.com/Robitx/gp.nvim"},{"title":"Claude Code + Neovim: AI-Powered Vim Plugins for Terminal Developers | Claude Directory","url":"https://www.claudedirectory.co/blog/claude-code-neovim-ai-powered-vim-plugins-for-terminal-developers"},{"title":"GitHub - carlos-rodrigo/claude-code.nvim: Neovim plugin for seamless Claude Code integration with buffer management","url":"https://github.com/carlos-rodrigo/claude-code.nvim"},{"title":"GitHub - ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins: A list of Neovim AI community plugins","url":"https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins"},{"title":"GitHub - pasky/claude.vim: Claude vim plugin for AI pair programming - a hacker's gateway to LLMs","url":"https://github.com/pasky/claude.vim"},{"title":"https://github.com/coder/claudecode.nvim | Ecosyste.ms: Awesome","url":"https://awesome.ecosyste.ms/projects/github.com/coder/claudecode.nvim"},{"title":"I Built a Claude Code Context Modal Inside of Neovim | Daniel Miessler","url":"https://danielmiessler.com/blog/neovim-claude-ai-plugin"}]

Here are the search results for **"gp.nvim neovim plugin anthropic claude local file context 2025"**:

---

## gp.nvim (GPT Prompt for Neovim)

**gp.nvim** supports Anthropic to access Claude models (which currently outperform GPT-4 in some benchmarks), Google Gemini with a generous free range (but some geo-restrictions), and any other "OpenAI chat/completions" compatible endpoint (Azure, LM Studio, etc.).

### Provider Configuration

The plugin supports multiple provider configurations. For Anthropic, the endpoint is `https://api.anthropic.com/v1/messages` with the secret set via `os.getenv("ANTHROPIC_API_KEY")`. Each of these providers has some agents preconfigured.

---

## Other Notable Claude + Neovim Plugins (2025)

### 1. **claudecode.nvim** (by coder)
The first Neovim IDE integration for Claude Code — bringing Anthropic's AI coding assistant to your favorite editor with a pure Lua implementation. The author reverse-engineered Anthropic's VS Code/JetBrains extension and built this Neovim plugin, implementing the same WebSocket-based MCP protocol to give Neovim users the same AI-powered coding experience.

Key features include:
- Pure Lua with zero dependencies, built entirely with `vim.loop` and Neovim built-ins, and 100% protocol compatible with the same WebSocket MCP implementation as official extensions.
- You can add entire files, directories, or specific line ranges as context using the `:ClaudeCodeAdd` command (e.g., `:ClaudeCodeAdd src/main.lua 50 100` for lines 50 through 100).

### 2. **codecompanion.nvim** (by olimorris)
A polished editing flow reminiscent of Cursor, with strong diff/apply ergonomics and provider flexibility, including Claude via either direct provider settings or ACP bridges.

### 3. **parrot.nvim**
A lean, keyboard-first assistant that stores chats as Markdown and supports multiple providers, including Anthropic. A Neovim Discourse thread announced parrot.nvim's Anthropic support in 2025.

### 4. **claude.vim** (by pasky)
You can obtain your Claude API key by signing up at the Anthropic console. Anthropic might give you a free $5 credit to get started, which is plenty for many hours of hacking.

---

## General Recommendations for 2025

If you want Claude inside Neovim in 2025—chat, inline edits, repo-aware notes, or full Claude Code (ACP) workflows—the fastest path is to install a community plugin that already speaks to Anthropic's API or Claude Code bridges.

For API keys and models: create an API key in the Anthropic Console and pass it via an environment variable; choose models from the Anthropic Models overview (2025) rather than hard-coding names in your config.

For cost and safety: start with a smaller model for exploratory prompts and set sane limits (max tokens, temperature) where the plugin supports it.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's a summary of the search results for **codecompanion.nvim** with Anthropic Claude, context variables, system prompt, and user config:

## Key Findings

### Overview
CodeCompanion.nvim supports LLMs from Anthropic, Copilot, GitHub Models, DeepSeek, Gemini, Mistral AI, Novita, Ollama, OpenAI, Azure OpenAI, HuggingFace and xAI, as well as Agent Client Protocol support enabling coding with agents like Augment Code, Cagent from Docker, Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI, Goose, Kimi CLI, Kiro and OpenCode.

### Context Variables
You can add context from your code base by using Variables and Slash Commands in the chat buffer. Variables, accessed via `#`, contain data about the present state of Neovim: `#buffer` shares the current buffer's code. You can also specify line numbers with `#buffer:8-20`, `#lsp` shares LSP information and code for the current buffer, and `#viewport` shares the buffers and lines that you see in the Neovim viewport.

To send additional context alongside your prompt, you can leverage variables such as `:CodeCompanion #{buffer} <your prompt>`.

### System Prompt Configuration
If your chat buffer system prompt is still stored at `opts.system_prompt` you'll need to change it to `interactions.chat.opts.system_prompt`. This was part of a breaking change in a recent upgrade.

### Adapter Configuration for Anthropic
You can configure the Anthropic adapter like so: `interactions = { chat = { adapter = "anthropic", model = "claude-sonnet-4-20250514" } }`.

There are numerous ways that environment variables can be set for adapters, including extending the adapter with a custom `env` block specifying an alternate API key.

Because most LLMs require an API key, you'll need to share that with the adapter. By default, adapters will look in your environment for a `*_API_KEY` where `*` is the name of the adapter such as `ANTHROPIC` or `OPENAI`.

### Claude Code ACP Support (v17.21.0+)
The Zed team's Claude Code ACP adapter launched and so too has the CodeCompanion implementation. Users have asked about using an Anthropic API key with this instead of OAuth, for those using Claude Code with an API key instead of a pro or max plan.

### Using Bearer Token (OAuth-style like Claude Code)
To figure out how Claude Code manages authentication, one user found: It uses the same endpoint as API key users. A couple of headers are different when the request comes from Claude Code. Authentication is done using OAuth — it sends a bearer token in the Authorization header. A required system message is prepended to every prompt.

### Rules (formerly "Memory") for System-level Instructions
Memory has been renamed to rules. Please rename any references to memory in your configuration to rules.

You can set specific rule groups that will be automatically added to chat buffers. This is useful for ensuring that your preferred rules are always available.

The plugin has built-in parsers including `claude` which will import files into the chat buffer in the same way Claude Code does, and `CodeCompanion` which parses rules in the same way but allows for system prompts to be extracted via an H2 "System Prompt" header.

### Recent Upgrade Notes (v18+)
The biggest change in a recent release is the renaming of strategies to interactions. This will only be a breaking change if you specifically reference `codecompanion.strategies` in your configuration. Previously, built-in slash commands and tools were stored in `/catalog` folders which have now been renamed to `/builtin`.

The default adapters on the Anthropic and Gemini adapters have changed to `claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929` and `gemini-3-pro-preview`, respectively.

### Documentation
The documentation was last updated on February 6, 2026 for NVIM v0.11.

The exact query with the phrases "ask AI about my config" and "neovim help" didn't return direct matches, but the broader search revealed several relevant Neovim AI plugins that relate to asking AI about configurations, documentation, and providing context. Here's a summary of what's available:

## Neovim AI Plugins for Config Help & Documentation Context

### 1. **avante.nvim** (by yetone)
avante.nvim is a Neovim plugin designed to emulate the behaviour of the Cursor AI IDE. It provides users with AI-driven code suggestions and the ability to apply these recommendations directly to their source files with minimal effort. Key features include:
- AI-Powered Code Assistance: Interact with AI to ask questions about your current code file and receive intelligent suggestions for improvement or modification.
- The `avante.md` file allows you to provide project-specific context and instructions to the AI. This file should be placed in your project root and will be automatically referenced during all interactions with avante.

### 2. **codecompanion.nvim** (by olimorris)
A large proportion of issues raised in Neovim plugins are to do with a user's own config. That's why the author always asks users to fill in a minimal.lua file when they raise an issue, to rule out their config being an issue.

### 3. **Curated List: neovim-ai-plugins** (by ColinKennedy)
This is a list of Neovim AI plugins. This page is auto-generated and was last updated on "2026-02-25". It catalogs many AI plugins including ones for:
- Integrating ChatGPT-style LLMs into Neovim: ask questions, keep multi-file context
- Generating inline documentation for your functions using AI
- Efficiently sharing your project's most relevant context with AI

### 4. **gp.nvim** (GPT Prompt by Robitx)
Gp.nvim (GPT prompt) is a Neovim AI plugin offering ChatGPT sessions & Instructable text/code operations & Speech to text with support for OpenAI, Ollama, and Anthropic. Using `:GpChatRespond N` you can request a new GPT response with only the last N messages as context.

### 5. **vim-ai** (by madox2)
This plugin adds Artificial Intelligence (AI) capabilities to your Vim and Neovim. You can generate code, edit text, or have an interactive conversation with GPT models, all powered by OpenAI's API. In the context of this plugin, a role means a re-usable AI instruction and/or configuration. Roles are defined in the configuration .ini file.

### 6. **NeoCodeium**
NeoCodeium is a plugin that provides AI completion powered by Windsurf. You can chat with AI in the browser with the `:NeoCodeium chat` command. It should open a chat window in the browser with the context of the current buffer, where you can ask some specific questions about your code base.

### 7. **Neural** (by dense-analysis)
Neural integrates various machine learning tools so you can let AI write code for you in Neovim/Vim, among other helpful things. You can easily ask AI to explain code or paragraphs with `:NeuralExplain`.

---

No plugin specifically branded as "ask AI about my config" with "neovim help" documentation context was found. The closest matches for asking AI questions about your Neovim configuration with documentation context would be **avante.nvim** or **codecompanion.nvim**, both of which allow you to provide context (like your config files) and ask AI questions about them. If you have more details about the specific plugin you're looking for, I can refine the search.

Here's a summary of the search results for **avante.nvim with Anthropic Claude in Neovim (2025)**:

## Overview

avante.nvim is currently the bleeding-edge plugin trying to replicate the Cursor AI experience entirely within Neovim. It uses a sidebar chat interface and allows for inline applying of diffs.

Avante is set up using Claude from Anthropic by default but can be changed to use ChatGPT from OpenAI.

## Provider & Mode Configuration

The provider type alias supports `"claude" | "openai" | "azure" | "gemini" | "cohere" | "copilot"` and the default mode is `"agentic"`, which "uses tools to automatically generate code," while `"legacy"` uses the old planning method.

## Claude Code / ACP Integration

For Claude Code, you can install the acp-claude-code package via npm and set your `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`. ACP providers offer several advantages over traditional API-based providers: enhanced tool access, persistent context, fine-grained permissions, and a standardized protocol.

Currently supported ACP agents include `gemini-cli`, `claude-code`, `goose`, `codex`, and `kimi-cli`, configured in the `acp_providers` section of your configuration.

## Quick Setup with Claude

A typical configuration uses `provider = "claude"` with the endpoint `https://api.anthropic.com`, model `claude-sonnet-4-20250514`, temperature 0 for deterministic code output, and max_tokens of 8000.

You'll need to set up your API key via environment variable: `export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="sk-ant-your-key-here"` in your shell profile to keep secrets out of dotfiles.

## Key Commands for Q&A / Interaction

Key bindings include: Press `<leader>aa` to ask a question, `<leader>ae` to edit with AI assistance (in visual mode), `<leader>am` to select a model, `<leader>ap` to select AI provider, and `<C-c>` to toggle Claude Code sidebar.

For quick chat/Q&A, you can use `:AvanteAsk` followed by your question, e.g., "What does this function do?"

For inline edits, select code in visual mode and run `:AvanteEdit`. Model switching works via `:AvanteProvider claude` or `:AvanteProvider openai`.

## Slash Commands & Additional Features

In the input box, there is support for a few slash commands. Try `/help` for more information.

You can customize AI behavior by adding a markdown file (`avante.md` by default) in the project root, which is automatically referenced during workspace changes.

Avante also provides a RAG service for obtaining required context for AI code generation, though by default it is not enabled.

## Top Claude Neovim Plugins in 2025

According to a roundup from Skywork.ai, the top plugins with Claude support in 2025 include `olimorris/codecompanion.nvim`, `yetone/avante.nvim`, `coder/claudecode.nvim`, and `parrot.nvim`.

Parrot.nvim is described as "a lean, keyboard-first assistant that stores chats as Markdown and supports multiple providers, including Anthropic—great for quick prompts, refactors, and sticky notes alongside code."

## Known Issues

One reported bug (September 2025) involved Claude applying code changes directly to the buffer without showing the confirmation pop-up, unlike the Copilot provider behavior.

## Version Info

As of February 2026, avante.nvim version 0.0.9 was tested on Neovim 0.10.0 with Lazy.nvim 10.x, on macOS Sonoma and Ubuntu 24.04, using the Claude API model `claude-sonnet-4-20250514`.

Here's what I found about **parrot.nvim** and its Anthropic Claude integration for Neovim:

## parrot.nvim 🦜 — Stochastic Parrots for Neovim

parrot.nvim is the "ultimate stochastic parrot" to support text editing inside Neovim. It offers a seamless out-of-the-box experience, providing tight integration of current LLM APIs into Neovim workflows, with a focus solely on text generation.

### Key Features

- The selected core features include on-demand text completion and editing, as well as chat-like sessions within native Neovim buffers.
- Persistent conversations stored as markdown files within Neovim's standard path or a user-defined location. Custom hooks for inline text editing based on user instructions and chats with predefined system prompts.
- It does not have autocompletion or hidden requests in the background to analyze files.

### Privacy & Philosophy

This plugin is intended for people who actually know what they are doing and people who care for privacy and transparency. The user is always under full control of what will be sent to the LLM API endpoint, hence this plugin fully excludes the whole notion of agents provided by tools such as codex, claude-code, and the gemini-cli.

### Anthropic Claude Support

The plugin has first-class support for Anthropic's Claude models. The Anthropic provider configuration connects to `https://api.anthropic.com/v1/messages` and supports models including `claude-sonnet-4-20250514`, `claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219`, `claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022`, and `claude-3-5-haiku-20241022`.

### Multi-Provider Support

It supports persistent conversations as markdown files, custom hooks for inline text editing, multiple providers like Anthropic API, Perplexity.ai API, OpenAI API, Mistral API, and local/offline serving via ollama.

### Installation

The plugin requires the latest version of Neovim and relies on a carefully selected set of established plugins. Using lazy.nvim:

```lua
{
  "frankroeder/parrot.nvim",
  dependencies = { "ibhagwan/fzf-lua", "nvim-lua/plenary.nvim" },
  opts = {}
}
```

### Origin

While this project is still under development, a substantial part of the code is based on an early fork of the brilliant work by Tibor Schmidt's gp.nvim.

### Community Standing

parrot.nvim has earned 692 stars on GitHub and is tagged with topics including anthropic, claude, neovim, ollama, openai, and more. It stands out as "a lean, keyboard-first assistant that stores chats as Markdown and supports multiple providers, including Anthropic—great for quick prompts, refactors, and sticky notes alongside code."

**GitHub**: [frankroeder/parrot.nvim](https://github.com/frankroeder/parrot.nvim)

Minuet offers code completion as-you-type from popular LLMs including OpenAI, Gemini, Claude, Ollama, Llama.cpp, Codestral, and more.","url":"https://neovimcraft.com/plugin/milanglacier/minuet-ai.nvim/"}]

Here's what I found about **minuet-ai.nvim**:

## minuet-ai.nvim — 💃 Dance with Intelligence in Your Code

Minuet AI is a Neovim plugin that provides AI-powered code completion by integrating large language models (LLMs) directly into the editor. It functions as a bridge between various LLM providers and different completion display methods within Neovim, allowing developers to harness the power of AI code assistance while maintaining a native editor experience.

### Supported LLM Providers

Minuet offers code completion as-you-type from popular LLMs including OpenAI, Gemini, Claude, Ollama, Llama.cpp, Codestral, and more.

### Key Features

- Support for virtual-text, nvim-cmp, blink-cmp, built-in, and mini.completion frontends.
- Acts as an in-process LSP server to provide completions (opt-in feature).
- Accepts multi-line suggestions line-by-line, so longer suggestions can be pulled in incrementally at your own pace.
- When your typed text matches the start of a suggestion, Minuet keeps the completion in sync with your typed text rather than discarding it, to reduce unnecessary LLM requests and conserve resources.
- Specialized prompts and various enhancements for chat-based LLMs on code completion tasks.
- Fill-in-the-middle (FIM) completion for compatible models (DeepSeek, Codestral, Qwen, and others).
- Streaming support to enable completion delivery even with slower LLMs.
- It offers customizable configuration options and supports manual or automatic completion invocation.

### Requirements

- Neovim 0.10+.
- Neovim version 0.11 or higher is necessary for built-in completion.

### Architecture

Minuet is designed with a modular architecture that separates frontends (display methods), backends (LLM providers), and core infrastructure.

### Display Methods

Minuet offers four different methods to display completions: Virtual Text (ghost text inline with your code), nvim-cmp integration, blink-cmp integration, and LSP Server (functions as an in-process LSP server).

### Performance Notes

When assessing model speed, two key metrics are latency (time to first token) and throughput (tokens per second). Latency is often a more critical factor than throughput. Ideally, one would aim for a latency of less than 1 second and a throughput exceeding 100 tokens per second.

### Popularity

The plugin has earned approximately 1,023 stars on GitHub and supports Claude, DeepSeek, Ollama, OpenAI, and Windsurf, with the latest update as of February 2026.

### Installation

The plugin is available on GitHub at `milanglacier/minuet-ai.nvim` and is also available on luarocks.org — simply run `Rocks install minuet-ai.nvim` to install it like any other luarocks package.

The Power of Open-Source AI | Globant","url":"https://medium.com/globant/ollama-meets-neovim-9ab99e9b15af"},{"title":"GitHub - 3ZsForInsomnia/vs-code-companion: A CodeCompanion extension for using VS Code Copilot prompts and Chat Mode prompts","url":"https://github.com/3ZsForInsomnia/vs-code-companion"}]

Here are the search results for **codecompanion.nvim slash commands, context, #buffer, #lsp, custom context provider, system prompt configuration (2025)**:

---

## CodeCompanion.nvim — Slash Commands, Variables, Context & System Prompt Configuration

### Variables (`#`)

You can add context from your code base by using Variables and Slash Commands in the chat buffer. Variables, accessed via `#`, contain data about the present state of Neovim.

- **`#buffer`**: The buffer variable will automatically link a buffer to the chat buffer, by default, updating the LLM when the buffer changes. To send additional context alongside your prompt, you can leverage variables such as `:CodeCompanion #{buffer} <your prompt>`.

- **`#lsp`**: The `#lsp` variable has a callback of `"interactions.chat.variables.lsp"` and its description is "Share LSP information and code for the current buffer".

- **`#viewport`**: Also available in the config, it allows you to share the code visible in your Neovim viewport with the LLM.

### Slash Commands (`/`)

Slash commands, accessed via `/`, run commands to insert additional context into the chat buffer.

Built-in presets include:

The prompt library comes with the following presets: `/commit` (generate a commit message), `/explain` (explain how selected code in a buffer works), `/fix` (fix the selected code), `/lsp` (explain the LSP diagnostics for the selected code), and `/tests` (generate unit tests for selected code).

The **`/buffer`** slash command is configured in `config.lua`:

The `/buffer` slash command uses the callback `"interactions.chat.slash_commands.builtin.buffer"` with the description "Insert open buffers" and supports options like `contains_code = true` and `default_params = "diff"` (which can be `all` or `diff`).

### Custom Slash Commands

You can create your own custom slash commands. For example, a custom `git_files` slash command can be defined that runs `git ls-files`, then calls `chat:add_context()` to insert the results into the chat.

Example pattern:
```lua
require("codecompanion").setup({
  interactions = {
    chat = {
      slash_commands = {
        ["git_files"] = {
          description = "List git files",
          callback = function(chat)
            local handle = io.popen("git ls-files")
            if handle then
              local result = handle:read("*a")
              handle:close()
              chat:add_context({ role = "user", content = result }, "git", "<git_files>")
            end
          end,
          opts = { contains_code = false },
        },
      },
    },
  },
})
```

### Slash Command Provider Configuration

Each slash command may have their own unique configuration, so be sure to check out the `config.lua` file. The plugin supports providers like Telescope, mini_pick, fzf_lua, and snacks.nvim. By default, the plugin will automatically detect if you have any of those plugins installed and set them as the default provider.

### System Prompt Configuration

If your chat buffer system prompt is still stored at `opts.system_prompt`, you'll need to change it to `interactions.chat.opts.system_prompt`.

The default system prompt includes dynamic information:
The system prompt starts with "You are currently plugged in to the Neovim text editor on a user's machine. Your core task is to generate command-line inputs that the user can run within Neovim." (This is the Cmd interaction's system prompt.)

For the main chat, there is an option `replace_main_system_prompt` which controls whether to replace the main system prompt with the tools system prompt.

### Prompt Decorator

You can use a `prompt_decorator` function in `interactions.chat.opts` to decorate the user message before it's sent to the LLM. The decorator function also has access to the adapter in the chat buffer alongside the context table.

### Context Folding

It's not uncommon for users to share many items as context with an LLM. This can impact the chat buffer's UI significantly, leaving a large space between the LLM's last response and the user's input. To minimize this impact, the context can be folded using `display.chat.fold_context = true`.

### Upgrading Notes (v16+)

The biggest change in the latest release is the renaming of `strategies` to `interactions`. This will only be a breaking change if you specifically reference `codecompanion.strategies` in your configuration. Previously, built-in slash commands and tools were stored in `/catalog` folders which have now been renamed to `/builtin`.

Prompts also changed: you need to rename `opts.short_name` to `opts.alias` for each item in order to allow you to call them with `require("codecompanion").prompt("my_prompt")` or as slash commands in the chat buffer.

### Rules Support

The plugin supports rules files like `CLAUDE.md`, `.cursor/rules`, and your own custom ones.

---

For full documentation, visit the official docs at [codecompanion.olimorris.dev](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev) and the [config.lua source on GitHub](https://github.com/olimorris/codecompanion.nvim/blob/main/lua/codecompanion/config.lua).

Here are the search results for **gp.nvim chat hook system_prompt context file include custom agent anthropic**:

## gp.nvim - Neovim AI Plugin

**gp.nvim** (GPT prompt) is a Neovim AI plugin supporting ChatGPT sessions, instructable text/code operations, and speech to text with OpenAI, Ollama, Anthropic, and more.

### Provider Support (including Anthropic)

Anthropic is supported to access Claude models, which currently outperform GPT-4 in some benchmarks. Here's an example of configuring the Anthropic provider:

In your plugin config, you can set up providers including `anthropic` with the endpoint `https://api.anthropic.com/v1/messages` and a secret from an environment variable like `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`.

### Custom Agents & System Prompts

You can choose a new agent based on its name, listing options based on the current buffer (chat agents if current buffer is a chat and command agents otherwise). The agent setting is persisted on disk across Neovim instances.

The source code reveals that the system prompt is rendered via `M.render.prompt_template(agent.system_prompt, command, selection, filetype, filename)`, meaning system prompts support template variables for contextual information like the current file, filetype, and selection.

### Custom Hooks

A non-interactive command mode is available for common repetitive tasks implementable as simple hooks (explain something in a popup window, write unit tests for selected code into a new buffer, finish selected code based on comments in it, etc.).

For example, a custom hook can be defined like this:

An example hook `APIDoc` uses a template with placeholders like `{{filename}}`, `{{filetype}}`, and `{{selection}}` to generate API documentation for selected code.

### Context File (.gp.md)

Custom instructions per repository can be set with a `.gp.md` file to instruct GPT to generate code using certain libs, packages, conventions, and so on.

For private/less known code, you could dump a concise API reference for what you need into a `.gp.md` file in the root of a repo and all code operations would have it as context.

### Including File Context in Chats

A more manual, surgically precise option would be to gather relevant pieces of code from multiple files into a chat buffer with `:GpChatPaste` and let the model crunch it there.

### Setting a Default Agent

There's no official way documented to set the default agent on startup, but some users have resorted to using the undocumented/internal API `require("gp")._state` to achieve this.

### Related Plugin: parrot.nvim (fork of gp.nvim)

parrot.nvim is based on an early fork of gp.nvim and offers custom hooks for inline text editing based on user instructions and chats with predefined system prompts, along with a unified provider system supporting any OpenAI-compatible API.

Here's what I found about **folke/sidekick.nvim** — the Neovim AI sidekick plugin:

## Overview

sidekick.nvim is an AI-augmented coding assistant plugin for Neovim that operates through two independent but complementary subsystems: Next Edit Suggestions (NES), which integrates with copilot-language-server to display multi-line code refactorings. The CLI Integration manages terminal sessions for AI command-line tools (Claude, Aider, Gemini, etc.) with context-aware prompting and session persistence. The plugin requires Neovim >= 0.11.2 and exposes its functionality through Lua APIs, Vim commands, and optional statusline integrations.

Created by legendary Neovim plugin developer Folke, Sidekick.nvim brings GitHub Copilot's Next Edit Suggestions (NES) and integrated AI CLI tools directly into your favorite editor.

## Key Features

**Next Edit Suggestions (NES):** Multi-line refactorings and context-aware edits across your file. **AI CLI Integration:** Built-in terminal for Claude, Gemini, and other AI tools.

Additional highlights include:

- **Context-Aware Prompts:** Automatically include file content, cursor position, and diagnostics in your prompts.
- **Prompt Library:** A library of pre-defined prompts for common tasks like explaining code, fixing issues, or writing tests.
- **Session Persistence:** Keep your CLI sessions alive with tmux and zellij integration.
- **Automatic File Watching:** Automatically reloads files in Neovim when they are modified by AI tools.
- **Plugin-Friendly API:** A rich API for integrating with other plugins and building custom workflows.
- **Customizable UI:** Change the appearance of diffs, signs, and more.

## Copilot Requirement

Copilot is required, but only for the NES feature (Next Edit Suggestions). The AI CLI integration works independently with any CLI tool (Claude, Gemini, etc.) and doesn't require Copilot.

## Configuration

The module ships with safe defaults and exposes everything through `require("sidekick").setup({ ... })`.

The context system provides custom context functions that can be used in prompt templates. You can define custom tools, prompts, and keymaps. It comes with out-of-the-box support for Claude, Gemini, Grok, Codex, Copilot CLI, and more.

Run `:checkhealth sidekick` to see which tools are installed. Sidekick provides a `:Sidekick` command that allows you to interact with the plugin from the command line. The command is a thin wrapper around the Lua API, so you can use it to do anything that the Lua API can do.

## Development & Testing

Core modules live under `lua/sidekick/` (config.lua, nes/, status.lua, etc.). Tests are written with mini.test and live in `tests/`. Specs are table-driven whenever possible. Docs are generated automatically via `./scripts/docs`, which extracts Lua annotations to update README.md sections.

## Recent Activity

Recent development includes a treesitter context feature for class and function awareness. The plugin is actively maintained on GitHub at [folke/sidekick.nvim](https://github.com/folke/sidekick.nvim).

Here are the search results for your query about Neovim plugins related to RAG, vimdoc, help tags, indexing, AI querying, and local documentation in 2025:

---

## Key Findings

### 1. **Avante.nvim** — Cursor-like AI IDE for Neovim with RAG
Avante provides a RAG service, which is a tool for obtaining the required context for the AI to generate the codes. By default, it is not enabled. Additionally, RAG Service also depends on Docker! (For macOS users, OrbStack is recommended as a Docker alternative). The RAG service configuration includes settings for LLM provider, API endpoint, embedding model, and Docker mount paths.

### 2. **VectorCode** — Code Repository Indexing for RAG
VectorCode is a code repository indexing tool. It helps you write better prompts for your coding LLMs by indexing and providing information about the code repository you're working on. This repository also contains the corresponding Neovim plugin because that's what the author used to write the tool.

It integrates with **minuet-ai.nvim**: VectorCode contains two main components. The first is a standalone CLI program written in Python, available for installation via PyPI. This program is responsible for creating the vector database and processing RAG queries. The second component is a Neovim plugin that provides utility functions to send queries and manage buffer-related RAG information within Neovim.

### 3. **nvim-gemini-helper** — Gemini + RAG Support
There is a Neovim Gemini Helper plugin with RAG support.

### 4. **Minuet-ai.nvim** — AI Code Completion with RAG Integration
Minuet offers code completion as-you-type from popular LLMs including OpenAI, Gemini, Claude, Ollama, Llama.cpp, Codestral, and more. It integrates with VectorCode for RAG-based context retrieval. They offer two example recipes demonstrating VectorCode integration: one for chat-based LLMs (Gemini) and another for the FIM model (Qwen-2.5-Coder).

---

## Neovim's Native Help/Tag/Documentation System

### Vimdoc Help System
Nvim :help pages are generated from source using the tree-sitter-vimdoc parser. It is possible to go directly to whatever you want help on, by giving an argument to the :help command.

### Tags System
A tag is an identifier that appears in a "tags" file. It is a sort of label that can be jumped to. The "tags" file has to be generated by a program like ctags, before the tag commands can be used.

### Neovim Index
The Neovim index file contains a list of all commands for each mode, with a tag and a short description. The lists are sorted on ASCII value.

---

## Broader Neovim AI Plugin Landscape (2025)
In 2025, that means embedding AI copilots, instant table-driven Go tests, Lean proof states, and smarter completion ranking—all without sacrificing the muscle-memory-driven workflow that makes Vim great.

On **neovimcraft.com**, you can find plugins that write documentation in pandoc markdown and generate documentation in vimdoc. The site lists 37 plugins in the "ai" category among many other categories.

---

**Note:** I did not find a specific plugin that combines RAG specifically over *vimdoc/help tags* (i.e., using RAG to query local Neovim `:help` documentation with AI). The closest tools are **VectorCode** and **Avante.nvim's RAG service**, which index code repositories rather than vimdoc help files specifically. Building a RAG pipeline over vimdoc help files appears to be a niche that isn't yet fully addressed by existing plugins.

Here's a summary of what I found about **folke/sidekick.nvim** regarding context, prompts, custom configuration, keybindings, and more:

## Overview

sidekick.nvim is an AI-augmented coding assistant plugin for Neovim that operates through two independent but complementary subsystems: Next Edit Suggestions (NES) which integrates with copilot-language-server, and CLI Integration which manages terminal sessions for AI command-line tools (claude, aider, gemini, etc.) with context-aware prompting and session persistence. The plugin requires Neovim >= 0.11.2 and exposes its functionality through Lua APIs, Vim commands, and optional statusline integrations.

## Context System

The context system provides custom context functions that can be used in prompt templates. Built-in context providers are defined in `lua/sidekick/context/init.lua`.

You can also use context variables in your prompts to include information about the current file, selection, diagnostics, and more.

The special `{this}` variable has smart behavior: If the current buffer is a file, it resolves to `{position}`. Otherwise, it resolves to the literal string "this" and appends the current `{selection}` to the prompt.

The pipe `|` operator allows fallback context resolution: `{function|line}` — Try `{function}`, if not available use `{line}`. This is useful for prompts that should work in different contexts.

## Built-in Prompts

Sidekick comes with a set of predefined prompts that you can use with your AI tools. The default prompts include:

- `changes` — "Can you review my changes?"
- `diagnostics` — "Can you help me fix the diagnostics in {file}?"
- `document` — "Add documentation to {function|line}"
- `explain` — "Explain {this}"
- `fix` — "Can you fix {this}?"
- `optimize` — "How can {this} be optimized?"
- `review` — "Can you review {file} for any issues or improvements?"
- `tests` — "Can you write tests for {this}?"

Plus simple context prompts like `{buffers}`, `{file}`, `{line}`, `{position}`, `{quickfix}`, `{selection}`, `{function}`, and `{class}`.

You can use prompts with `<leader>ap` or `:Sidekick cli prompt`.

## Custom Keybindings

You can customize the keymaps for the CLI window by setting the `cli.win.keys` option. For example, you can override the default hide keymap or add new keymaps as shown in the README.

### Default Key Mappings

Key default keybindings from the recommended config include:

| Keybinding | Description |
|---|---|
| `<Tab>` | Goto/Apply Next Edit Suggestion |
| `<C-.>` | Sidekick Toggle (all modes) |
| `<leader>aa` | Sidekick Toggle CLI |
| `<leader>as` | Select CLI tool |
| `<leader>ad` | Detach a CLI Session |
| `<leader>at` | Send `{this}` context |

## Snacks.nvim Picker Integration

If you're using snacks.nvim, you can send picker selections directly to Sidekick's AI CLI tools. This is useful for sending search results, grep matches, or file selections as context. With the appropriate configuration, pressing `<a-a>` in any Snacks picker will send the selected items to your current AI CLI session.

## Configuration

Configuration is managed through the `sidekick.Config` class and initialized via `require("sidekick").setup({ ... })`. The configuration system uses a deep merge strategy where user-provided options are merged with default values.

Users can disable NES globally with `vim.g.sidekick_nes = false` or per-buffer with `vim.b.sidekick_nes = false`.

## Health Check & Asking Questions

Run `:checkhealth sidekick` to see which CLI tools are installed. For questions, explore the GitHub Discussions forum for folke/sidekick.nvim to discuss code, ask questions, and collaborate with the developer community.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.text:
---

# Neovim AI Q&A Plugins: Research Report

## Your Current Setup Context

You are running lazy.nvim with 34 plugins (no AI chat plugin currently installed). You already use `vim-slime` for sending prompts to external AI CLIs (Claude Code, opencode, codex) via tmux. Your `<leader>a` prefix is dedicated to agent operations. You use `fzf-lua` as your fuzzy finder.

---

## 1. codecompanion.nvim (RECOMMENDED -- Best Fit)

**Repository**: [olimorris/codecompanion.nvim](https://github.com/olimorris/codecompanion.nvim)  
**Docs**: [codecompanion.olimorris.dev](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/getting-started)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Yes, strongly.** Three mechanisms:

1. **Rules system** (formerly "memory"): Automatically loads files like `CLAUDE.md`, `.cursorrules`, etc. into every chat. You can define custom rule groups that glob your entire nvim config directory:

```lua
rules = {
  nvim_config = {
    description = "My Neovim configuration",
    files = {
      { path = "~/.config/nvim", files = "*.lua" },
      "~/.config/nvim/lazy-lock.json",
    },
  },
  opts = {
    chat = { autoload = "nvim_config" },
  },
}
```

2. **Custom slash commands**: You can build a `/myconfig` slash command that reads and injects your config files into the chat buffer on demand.

3. **Prompt library with file context**: Pre-define a "Neovim Help" prompt that automatically includes specific files:

```lua
["Neovim Help"] = {
  interaction = "chat",
  description = "Ask about my Neovim setup",
  context = {
    { type = "file", path = {
      "~/.config/nvim/lua/config/keymaps.lua",
      "~/.config/nvim/lua/config/options.lua",
      "~/.config/nvim/lazy-lock.json",
    }},
  },
  prompts = {
    { role = "system", content = "You are a Neovim expert. Answer based on the user's actual config." },
    { role = "user", content = "" },  -- user fills in
  },
}
```

### Can it include installed plugin documentation/help files?

**Partially.** There is no built-in "index all vimdoc" feature, but you can:
- Use the `/file` slash command to manually include any help file from `~/.local/share/nvim/lazy/*/doc/*.txt`
- Build a custom slash command that greps help tags and injects relevant doc sections
- Use the `#buffer` variable when you have a help buffer open

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Yes, first-class.** Direct adapter for Anthropic with model selection. Also supports Claude Code via ACP (Agent Client Protocol) in v17.21+. You can specify `claude-3-5-haiku-20241022` as the model for fast/cheap Q&A.

```lua
interactions = {
  chat = {
    adapter = "anthropic",
    opts = {
      model = "claude-3-5-haiku-20241022",  -- fast & cheap
    },
  },
}
```

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Medium.** Dependencies: `plenary.nvim` (you already have it), optionally `nvim-treesitter` (you already have it). The plugin itself is well-structured Lua. Configuration can be minimal or extensive.

### Typical interaction flow

1. Press keymap (e.g., `<leader>ai`) to open inline chat or `<leader>ac` for chat buffer
2. Type `#buffer` to include current buffer, or use `/file` to pick files
3. Ask your question
4. Answer appears in the chat buffer (streamed)

Or with the prompt library approach:
1. `:CodeCompanion` followed by your question -- single-shot Q&A
2. The pre-configured system prompt + your config files are automatically included
3. Answer streams inline or in a popup

### Advantages for your use case

- The **Rules system** is exactly what you need: auto-inject your nvim config into every chat
- The **Prompt Library** lets you create a dedicated "Neovim Help" prompt with pre-loaded context
- Custom system prompt can include `ctx.nvim_version`, `ctx.os`, and you can append your plugin list
- Supports `fzf_lua` as a provider (you already have `fzf-lua`)
- Active development (last update February 2026)

### Disadvantages

- No built-in vimdoc RAG/indexing
- Not the simplest plugin -- has many features you may not need

---

## 2. avante.nvim

**Repository**: [yetone/avante.nvim](https://github.com/yetone/avante.nvim)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Limited.** It reads an `avante.md` file from the project root for project-specific context. There is no equivalent of codecompanion's Rules system that auto-loads arbitrary file paths. You would need to maintain a separate `avante.md` describing your Neovim setup.

### Can it include installed plugin documentation/help files?

**Only via RAG**, which requires Docker and is not lightweight. The RAG service indexes code repositories, not vimdoc help files specifically.

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Yes.** Claude is the default provider. Supports model selection including Haiku.

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Heavy.** Requires a Rust build step (`cargo build`), has many dependencies. The RAG feature requires Docker. This is designed as a full Cursor-replacement IDE experience, not a lightweight Q&A tool.

### Typical interaction flow

Press `<leader>aa` to open a sidebar, type a question, get a response. The `:AvanteAsk "your question"` command works for quick questions.

### Verdict

**Overkill for this use case.** Avante is optimized for code generation and editing with diffs, not lightweight Q&A about your config. The sidebar-heavy UI is designed for Cursor-like workflows. Also note the `<leader>aa` keymap conflicts with your existing agent pane attach binding.

---

## 3. gp.nvim

**Repository**: [Robitx/gp.nvim](https://github.com/Robitx/gp.nvim)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Partially.** It supports a `.gp.md` file per repository for custom instructions/context. System prompts support template variables (`{{filename}}`, `{{filetype}}`, `{{selection}}`). However, there is no auto-loading of arbitrary config files into every chat. You would need to manually paste config via `:GpChatPaste`.

### Can it include installed plugin documentation/help files?

**No built-in mechanism.** Manual paste only.

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Yes.** Supports Anthropic provider with Claude models, including Haiku.

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Very lightweight.** Minimal dependencies. Chats are stored as plain markdown files. Philosophy emphasizes simplicity and user control.

### Typical interaction flow

`:GpChatNew` opens a new chat in a split. Type your question, press `<C-g><C-g>` (or custom keymap) to send. Responses appear inline in the markdown buffer.

### Verdict

**Good for lightweight chat, weak on auto-context.** The simplicity is appealing, but the lack of automatic config injection means you would need to manually provide context each time. Note that gp.nvim's development has slowed; `parrot.nvim` (its fork) is more actively maintained.

---

## 4. parrot.nvim (Fork of gp.nvim)

**Repository**: [frankroeder/parrot.nvim](https://github.com/frankroeder/parrot.nvim)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Same limitations as gp.nvim.** Custom hooks with system prompts, but no auto-loading of config files.

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Yes.** First-class Anthropic support including `claude-3-5-haiku-20241022`.

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Lightweight.** Dependencies: `fzf-lua` (you have it) and `plenary.nvim` (you have it). Chats stored as markdown.

### Verdict

**Better-maintained gp.nvim, but same context limitations.** Good for simple chat workflows but does not solve the "auto-inject my config" requirement.

---

## 5. minuet-ai.nvim

**Repository**: [milanglacier/minuet-ai.nvim](https://github.com/milanglacier/minuet-ai.nvim)

### Verdict

**Not relevant to this use case.** Minuet is exclusively a code completion (autocomplete/ghost-text) plugin. It does not provide chat or Q&A functionality. It supports Claude for inline completions, but there is no way to ask questions about your config.

---

## 6. sidekick.nvim (NEW -- Worth considering)

**Repository**: [folke/sidekick.nvim](https://github.com/folke/sidekick.nvim)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Yes, via context system.** It automatically includes file content, cursor position, and diagnostics. It supports context variables like `{file}`, `{selection}`, `{function}`, `{buffers}`, `{diagnostics}`. Custom context functions can be defined. However, it does not auto-load arbitrary files like codecompanion's Rules.

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Indirectly.** Sidekick wraps CLI tools (Claude Code, Gemini CLI, Aider, etc.) rather than calling APIs directly. For your use case of "lightweight Haiku Q&A," this is a mismatch -- it would need Claude Code running as a CLI process, which is not cheap Haiku calls.

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Requires Neovim >= 0.11.2** and a Copilot subscription for NES features. The CLI integration part works without Copilot but needs external CLI tools installed.

### Typical interaction flow

`<leader>aa` toggles the CLI panel. `<leader>at` sends `{this}` context. You interact with Claude Code (or other CLI) in a terminal split within Neovim.

### Verdict

**Different paradigm.** Sidekick is a wrapper around external AI CLIs, not a direct API caller. It does not let you send cheap Haiku API calls. It is better suited if you want to enhance your existing Claude Code + tmux workflow with better context injection. Given that you already have a similar vim-slime setup, sidekick would be a more polished version of what you already do, but it still does not address the "quick Haiku Q&A about my config" requirement.

---

## 7. No plugin specifically indexes vimdoc + user config for Q&A

After thorough research, no existing plugin specifically builds a searchable index over Neovim help documentation and user configuration for AI-powered Q&A. The closest approaches are:

- **VectorCode** (RAG indexing tool that integrates with minuet-ai.nvim) -- indexes code repos, not vimdoc
- **Avante's RAG service** -- requires Docker, indexes code, not help files
- **codecompanion's Rules + custom slash commands** -- the most flexible approach to manually construct this

---

## Recommendation

**codecompanion.nvim is the clear winner** for your use case. Here is why and how to set it up:

### Proposed architecture

```
Keymap (<leader>nh)  -->  CodeCompanion prompt "Neovim Help"
                           |
                           +-- System prompt: "You are a Neovim expert..."
                           +-- Auto-loaded context (Rules):
                           |     - lazy-lock.json (plugin list)
                           |     - config/keymaps.lua
                           |     - config/options.lua
                           |     - config/autocmds.lua
                           +-- Adapter: Anthropic claude-3-5-haiku
                           |
                           v
                     Answer in chat buffer or floating window
```

### Minimal configuration sketch

```lua
{
  "olimorris/codecompanion.nvim",
  dependencies = {
    "nvim-lua/plenary.nvim",
    "nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter",
  },
  keys = {
    { "<leader>nc", "<cmd>CodeCompanionChat Toggle<cr>", desc = "Nvim AI chat" },
    { "<leader>nh", function()
      require("codecompanion").prompt("nvim_help")
    end, desc = "Nvim help Q&A" },
  },
  opts = {
    adapters = {
      haiku = function()
        return require("codecompanion.adapters").extend("anthropic", {
          schema = { model = { default = "claude-3-5-haiku-20241022" } },
        })
      end,
    },
    interactions = {
      chat = {
        adapter = "haiku",
        opts = {
          system_prompt = function(ctx)
            return string.format([[
You are a Neovim configuration expert. The user is running Neovim %s on %s.
Answer questions about Neovim usage, keymaps, plugins, and configuration
based on the user's actual setup provided as context.
Be concise and practical. Reference specific keymaps and plugin names.
]], ctx.nvim_version, ctx.os)
          end,
        },
      },
    },
    rules = {
      nvim_setup = {
        description = "User Neovim configuration files",
        files = {
          vim.fn.expand("~/.config/nvim/lazy-lock.json"),
          { path = vim.fn.expand("~/.config/nvim/lua/config"), files = "*.lua" },
          { path = vim.fn.expand("~/.config/nvim/lua/plugins"), files = "*.lua" },
        },
      },
      opts = {
        chat = { autoload = "nvim_setup" },
      },
    },
    prompt_library = {
      ["nvim_help"] = {
        interaction = "chat",
        description = "Ask about Neovim setup",
        opts = { alias = "nh", is_default = false },
        prompts = {
          {
            role = "user",
            content = "",
            opts = { auto_submit = false },
          },
        },
      },
    },
  },
}
```

### Flow

1. Press `<leader>nh` -- opens chat buffer with your config already loaded as context
2. Type your question: "How do I use the surround plugin?" or "What keymap opens lazygit?"
3. Haiku answers based on your actual `keymaps.lua`, `lazy-lock.json`, etc.
4. Cost: roughly $0.001 per question with Haiku

### For vimdoc inclusion (optional enhancement)

You could build a custom slash command that greps help tags and injects relevant documentation:

```lua
interactions = {
  chat = {
    slash_commands = {
      ["help"] = {
        description = "Include Neovim help for a topic",
        callback = function(chat)
          vim.ui.input({ prompt = "Help topic: " }, function(topic)
            if not topic then return end
            local help_file = vim.fn.expand("$VIMRUNTIME/doc/" .. topic .. ".txt")
            if vim.fn.filereadable(help_file) == 1 then
              local content = table.concat(vim.fn.readfile(help_file), "\n")
              chat:add_context({ role = "user", content = content }, "help", "<help:" .. topic .. ">")
            end
          end)
        end,
      },
    },
  },
},
```

---

## Summary Matrix

| Plugin | Auto-inject config | Plugin docs | Claude/Haiku | Weight | Q&A flow |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **codecompanion.nvim** | Rules system (glob) | Custom slash cmd | Native adapter | Medium | Keymap -> chat -> answer |
| avante.nvim | avante.md only | RAG (Docker) | Native adapter | Heavy | Sidebar-based |
| gp.nvim | .gp.md only | Manual paste | Native adapter | Light | Split markdown chat |
| parrot.nvim | No auto-load | Manual paste | Native adapter | Light | Split markdown chat |
| sidekick.nvim | Context vars | No | CLI wrapper only | Medium | CLI terminal panel |
| minuet-ai.nvim | N/A | N/A | Yes | Light | Completion only (no Q&A) |

**codecompanion.nvim** is the only plugin that satisfies all your requirements: automatic config context injection (Rules), Anthropic Haiku support, quick keymap-to-answer flow, and extensibility for including help docs.

---

Sources:
- [olimorris/codecompanion.nvim GitHub](https://github.com/olimorris/codecompanion.nvim)
- [CodeCompanion Documentation](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/getting-started)
- [CodeCompanion Rules Configuration](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/configuration/rules)
- [CodeCompanion Chat Buffer Configuration](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/configuration/chat-buffer)
- [CodeCompanion Prompt Library](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/configuration/prompt-library)
- [yetone/avante.nvim GitHub](https://github.com/yetone/avante.nvim)
- [Robitx/gp.nvim GitHub](https://github.com/Robitx/gp.nvim)
- [frankroeder/parrot.nvim GitHub](https://github.com/frankroeder/parrot.nvim)
- [folke/sidekick.nvim GitHub](https://github.com/folke/sidekick.nvim)
- [milanglacier/minuet-ai.nvim GitHub](https://github.com/milanglacier/minuet-ai.nvim)
- [ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins (comprehensive list)](https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins)
- [Top 4 Claude Neovim Plugins 2025](https://skywork.ai/blog/claude-neovim-plugins-2025/)
- [CodeCompanion config.lua](https://github.com/olimorris/codecompanion.nvim/blob/main/lua/codecompanion/config.lua)
