Or with the prompt library approach:
1. `:CodeCompanion` followed by your question -- single-shot Q&A
2. The pre-configured system prompt + your config files are automatically included
3. Answer streams inline or in a popup

### Advantages for your use case

- The **Rules system** is exactly what you need: auto-inject your nvim config into every chat
- The **Prompt Library** lets you create a dedicated "Neovim Help" prompt with pre-loaded context
- Custom system prompt can include `ctx.nvim_version`, `ctx.os`, and you can append your plugin list
- Supports `fzf_lua` as a provider (you already have `fzf-lua`)
- Active development (last update February 2026)

### Disadvantages

- No built-in vimdoc RAG/indexing
- Not the simplest plugin -- has many features you may not need

---

## 2. avante.nvim

**Repository**: [yetone/avante.nvim](https://github.com/yetone/avante.nvim)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Limited.** It reads an `avante.md` file from the project root for project-specific context. There is no equivalent of codecompanion's Rules system that auto-loads arbitrary file paths. You would need to maintain a separate `avante.md` describing your Neovim setup.

### Can it include installed plugin documentation/help files?

**Only via RAG**, which requires Docker and is not lightweight. The RAG service indexes code repositories, not vimdoc help files specifically.

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Yes.** Claude is the default provider. Supports model selection including Haiku.

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Heavy.** Requires a Rust build step (`cargo build`), has many dependencies. The RAG feature requires Docker. This is designed as a full Cursor-replacement IDE experience, not a lightweight Q&A tool.

### Typical interaction flow

Press `<leader>aa` to open a sidebar, type a question, get a response. The `:AvanteAsk "your question"` command works for quick questions.

### Verdict

**Overkill for this use case.** Avante is optimized for code generation and editing with diffs, not lightweight Q&A about your config. The sidebar-heavy UI is designed for Cursor-like workflows. Also note the `<leader>aa` keymap conflicts with your existing agent pane attach binding.

---

## 3. gp.nvim

**Repository**: [Robitx/gp.nvim](https://github.com/Robitx/gp.nvim)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Partially.** It supports a `.gp.md` file per repository for custom instructions/context. System prompts support template variables (`{{filename}}`, `{{filetype}}`, `{{selection}}`). However, there is no auto-loading of arbitrary config files into every chat. You would need to manually paste config via `:GpChatPaste`.

### Can it include installed plugin documentation/help files?

**No built-in mechanism.** Manual paste only.

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Yes.** Supports Anthropic provider with Claude models, including Haiku.

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Very lightweight.** Minimal dependencies. Chats are stored as plain markdown files. Philosophy emphasizes simplicity and user control.

### Typical interaction flow

`:GpChatNew` opens a new chat in a split. Type your question, press `<C-g><C-g>` (or custom keymap) to send. Responses appear inline in the markdown buffer.

### Verdict

**Good for lightweight chat, weak on auto-context.** The simplicity is appealing, but the lack of automatic config injection means you would need to manually provide context each time. Note that gp.nvim's development has slowed; `parrot.nvim` (its fork) is more actively maintained.

---

## 4. parrot.nvim (Fork of gp.nvim)

**Repository**: [frankroeder/parrot.nvim](https://github.com/frankroeder/parrot.nvim)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Same limitations as gp.nvim.** Custom hooks with system prompts, but no auto-loading of config files.

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Yes.** First-class Anthropic support including `claude-3-5-haiku-20241022`.

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Lightweight.** Dependencies: `fzf-lua` (you have it) and `plenary.nvim` (you have it). Chats stored as markdown.

### Verdict

**Better-maintained gp.nvim, but same context limitations.** Good for simple chat workflows but does not solve the "auto-inject my config" requirement.

---

## 5. minuet-ai.nvim

**Repository**: [milanglacier/minuet-ai.nvim](https://github.com/milanglacier/minuet-ai.nvim)

### Verdict

**Not relevant to this use case.** Minuet is exclusively a code completion (autocomplete/ghost-text) plugin. It does not provide chat or Q&A functionality. It supports Claude for inline completions, but there is no way to ask questions about your config.

---

## 6. sidekick.nvim (NEW -- Worth considering)

**Repository**: [folke/sidekick.nvim](https://github.com/folke/sidekick.nvim)

### Can it include user's nvim config as context automatically?

**Yes, via context system.** It automatically includes file content, cursor position, and diagnostics. It supports context variables like `{file}`, `{selection}`, `{function}`, `{buffers}`, `{diagnostics}`. Custom context functions can be defined. However, it does not auto-load arbitrary files like codecompanion's Rules.

### Does it support Anthropic/Claude API?

**Indirectly.** Sidekick wraps CLI tools (Claude Code, Gemini CLI, Aider, etc.) rather than calling APIs directly. For your use case of "lightweight Haiku Q&A," this is a mismatch -- it would need Claude Code running as a CLI process, which is not cheap Haiku calls.

### How lightweight is the setup?

**Requires Neovim >= 0.11.2** and a Copilot subscription for NES features. The CLI integration part works without Copilot but needs external CLI tools installed.

### Typical interaction flow

`<leader>aa` toggles the CLI panel. `<leader>at` sends `{this}` context. You interact with Claude Code (or other CLI) in a terminal split within Neovim.

### Verdict

**Different paradigm.** Sidekick is a wrapper around external AI CLIs, not a direct API caller. It does not let you send cheap Haiku API calls. It is better suited if you want to enhance your existing Claude Code + tmux workflow with better context injection. Given that you already have a similar vim-slime setup, sidekick would be a more polished version of what you already do, but it still does not address the "quick Haiku Q&A about my config" requirement.

---

## 7. No plugin specifically indexes vimdoc + user config for Q&A

After thorough research, no existing plugin specifically builds a searchable index over Neovim help documentation and user configuration for AI-powered Q&A. The closest approaches are:

- **VectorCode** (RAG indexing tool that integrates with minuet-ai.nvim) -- indexes code repos, not vimdoc
- **Avante's RAG service** -- requires Docker, indexes code, not help files
- **codecompanion's Rules + custom slash commands** -- the most flexible approach to manually construct this

---

## Recommendation

**codecompanion.nvim is the clear winner** for your use case. Here is why and how to set it up:

### Proposed architecture

```
Keymap (<leader>nh)  -->  CodeCompanion prompt "Neovim Help"
                           |
                           +-- System prompt: "You are a Neovim expert..."
                           +-- Auto-loaded context (Rules):
                           |     - lazy-lock.json (plugin list)
                           |     - config/keymaps.lua
                           |     - config/options.lua
                           |     - config/autocmds.lua
                           +-- Adapter: Anthropic claude-3-5-haiku
                           |
                           v
                     Answer in chat buffer or floating window
```

### Minimal configuration sketch

```lua
{
  "olimorris/codecompanion.nvim",
  dependencies = {
    "nvim-lua/plenary.nvim",
    "nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter",
  },
  keys = {
    { "<leader>nc", "<cmd>CodeCompanionChat Toggle<cr>", desc = "Nvim AI chat" },
    { "<leader>nh", function()
      require("codecompanion").prompt("nvim_help")
    end, desc = "Nvim help Q&A" },
  },
  opts = {
    adapters = {
      haiku = function()
        return require("codecompanion.adapters").extend("anthropic", {
          schema = { model = { default = "claude-3-5-haiku-20241022" } },
        })
      end,
    },
    interactions = {
      chat = {
        adapter = "haiku",
        opts = {
          system_prompt = function(ctx)
            return string.format([[
You are a Neovim configuration expert. The user is running Neovim %s on %s.
Answer questions about Neovim usage, keymaps, plugins, and configuration
based on the user's actual setup provided as context.
Be concise and practical. Reference specific keymaps and plugin names.
]], ctx.nvim_version, ctx.os)
          end,
        },
      },
    },
    rules = {
      nvim_setup = {
        description = "User Neovim configuration files",
        files = {
          vim.fn.expand("~/.config/nvim/lazy-lock.json"),
          { path = vim.fn.expand("~/.config/nvim/lua/config"), files = "*.lua" },
          { path = vim.fn.expand("~/.config/nvim/lua/plugins"), files = "*.lua" },
        },
      },
      opts = {
        chat = { autoload = "nvim_setup" },
      },
    },
    prompt_library = {
      ["nvim_help"] = {
        interaction = "chat",
        description = "Ask about Neovim setup",
        opts = { alias = "nh", is_default = false },
        prompts = {
          {
            role = "user",
            content = "",
            opts = { auto_submit = false },
          },
        },
      },
    },
  },
}
```

### Flow

1. Press `<leader>nh` -- opens chat buffer with your config already loaded as context
2. Type your question: "How do I use the surround plugin?" or "What keymap opens lazygit?"
3. Haiku answers based on your actual `keymaps.lua`, `lazy-lock.json`, etc.
4. Cost: roughly $0.001 per question with Haiku

### For vimdoc inclusion (optional enhancement)

You could build a custom slash command that greps help tags and injects relevant documentation:

```lua
interactions = {
  chat = {
    slash_commands = {
      ["help"] = {
        description = "Include Neovim help for a topic",
        callback = function(chat)
          vim.ui.input({ prompt = "Help topic: " }, function(topic)
            if not topic then return end
            local help_file = vim.fn.expand("$VIMRUNTIME/doc/" .. topic .. ".txt")
            if vim.fn.filereadable(help_file) == 1 then
              local content = table.concat(vim.fn.readfile(help_file), "\n")
              chat:add_context({ role = "user", content = content }, "help", "<help:" .. topic .. ">")
            end
          end)
        end,
      },
    },
  },
},
```

---

## Summary Matrix

| Plugin | Auto-inject config | Plugin docs | Claude/Haiku | Weight | Q&A flow |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **codecompanion.nvim** | Rules system (glob) | Custom slash cmd | Native adapter | Medium | Keymap -> chat -> answer |
| avante.nvim | avante.md only | RAG (Docker) | Native adapter | Heavy | Sidebar-based |
| gp.nvim | .gp.md only | Manual paste | Native adapter | Light | Split markdown chat |
| parrot.nvim | No auto-load | Manual paste | Native adapter | Light | Split markdown chat |
| sidekick.nvim | Context vars | No | CLI wrapper only | Medium | CLI terminal panel |
| minuet-ai.nvim | N/A | N/A | Yes | Light | Completion only (no Q&A) |

**codecompanion.nvim** is the only plugin that satisfies all your requirements: automatic config context injection (Rules), Anthropic Haiku support, quick keymap-to-answer flow, and extensibility for including help docs.

---

Sources:
- [olimorris/codecompanion.nvim GitHub](https://github.com/olimorris/codecompanion.nvim)
- [CodeCompanion Documentation](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/getting-started)
- [CodeCompanion Rules Configuration](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/configuration/rules)
- [CodeCompanion Chat Buffer Configuration](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/configuration/chat-buffer)
- [CodeCompanion Prompt Library](https://codecompanion.olimorris.dev/configuration/prompt-library)
- [yetone/avante.nvim GitHub](https://github.com/yetone/avante.nvim)

- [CodeCompanion config.lua](https://github.com/olimorris/codecompanion.nvim/blob/main/lua/codecompanion/config.lua)

リサーチ結果をまとめます。

## 調査結果

主要なNeovim AIプラグイン6つを調査した結果、要件を満たすのは **codecompanion.nvim** のみでした。

| プラグイン | config自動注入 | プラグインdocs | Haiku対応 | 重さ |

| gp.nvim | .gp.mdのみ | 手動ペースト | Native | 軽 |
| parrot.nvim | なし | 手動ペースト | Native | 軽 |

## codecompanion.nvim が最適な理由

1. **Rules system** - `config/nvim/lua/` 配下のファイルをglobで自動的にチャットコンテキストに注入できる。keymaps.lua、options.lua、各plugin設定が自動で含まれる
2. **Prompt Library** - 「Neovim Help」専用プロンプトを定義でき、システムプロンプトで「Neovimの使い方に答えるエキスパート」として振る舞わせられる
3. **Anthropic Haiku ネイティブ対応** - `claude-3-5-haiku` を直接指定可能
4. **fzf-lua 連携** - 既存のfzf-luaをプロバイダーとして利用可能
5. **依存** - plenary.nvim + treesitter（両方すでにインストール済み）

### 想定フロー

```
<leader>nh → チャットバッファ開く（config全ファイルが自動コンテキスト）
  → 質問入力: "surroundの使い方は？"
  → Haiku が実際のkeymaps.lua等を参照して回答
```

input.prompt:
Research Neovim plugins that help users quickly ask questions about Neovim usage itself (not code generation, not coding assistants). The user wants to be inside Neovim and quickly ask things like:
- "How do I delete a word in Neovim?"
- "How do I use macros?"
- "What does ctrl-w do?"
- "How do I search and replace?"
- "How do I use registers?"

This is about learning/querying Neovim itself, not about writing code with AI help.

Search with these varied terms and angles:
1. "neovim AI help" "ask AI about vim"
2. "neovim plugin explain vim commands"
3. "neovim plugin LLM help documentation"
4. "vim AI tutor plugin"
5. "neovim :help AI" "smart help neovim"
6. "wtf.nvim" and similar error/explanation plugins
7. "neovim plugin ask question" "neovim chatbot"
8. "helpgpt" "vimgpt" "vim AI"
9. GitHub search for repos with "neovim" + "help" + "AI" or "LLM"
10. "neovim plugin natural language" "vim natural language commands"
11. Look for plugins that enhance or replace :help with AI-powered explanations
12. "nvim-help-ai" "vim-help-ai" "neovim-tutor-ai"
13. Any plugin that feeds :help docs to an LLM
14. Reddit/HackerNews discussions about "asking AI about vim from within vim"
15. "explain.nvim" "tutor.nvim" "mentor.nvim" "guide.nvim" "assist.nvim"

For EACH plugin found, report:
- Name and GitHub URL
- What it actually does (one line)
- Does it support Claude/Anthropic?
- Is it actively maintained (last commit date)?
- How simple is the interaction? (keymap → answer flow)

Also check if there are any lightweight single-file plugins or even vim commands/scripts that just pipe a question to an API and show the result. Sometimes the simplest solution is a 20-line Lua function, not a full plugin.

Do NOT limit to just "popular" plugins. Include niche, small, single-purpose tools.

Here are the results for your search on "vim AI tutor plugin neovim learn vim with AI":

## Key Vim/Neovim AI Plugins Found

### 1. **vim-ai** (by madox2)
This plugin adds Artificial Intelligence (AI) capabilities to your Vim and Neovim. You can generate code, edit text, or have an interactive conversation with GPT models, all powered by OpenAI's API. vim-ai can now be extended with custom provider plugins.

- GitHub: https://github.com/madox2/vim-ai

### 2. **avante.nvim** (by yetone)
Open a code file in Neovim. Use the `:AvanteAsk` command to query the AI about the code. Review the AI's suggestions. Apply the recommended changes directly to your code with a simple command or key binding. The plugin is still under active development, and both its functionality and interface are subject to significant changes.

- GitHub: https://github.com/yetone/avante.nvim

### 3. **Neural** (by dense-analysis)
A Neovim/Vim coding agent plugin. Neural integrates various machine learning tools so you can let AI write code for you in Neovim/Vim, among other helpful things. Use OpenAI's APIs made famous with ChatGPT, in Vim, or other local models.

- Site: https://neovimcraft.com/plugin/dense-analysis/neural/

### 4. **ai.vim** (by aduros)
A minimalist Neovim plugin for generating and editing text using OpenAI and GPT. Complete text in insert mode. Generate new text using a prompt. Select and edit existing text in-place.

- GitHub: https://github.com/aduros/ai.vim

### 5. **VimLM**
VimLM aims to seamlessly integrate LLMs into this workflow. By default, VimLM uses an uncensored Llama 3.2 3B model with token limit of 2000. VimLM bridges this gap, giving you AI assistance without leaving your favorite editor.

### 6. **Comprehensive List of Neovim AI Plugins**
There is a curated list of Neovim AI plugins, auto-generated and last updated on "2026-02-25". You can browse it at: https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins

---

### On Learning Vim with AI
The search didn't surface a dedicated "AI Vim tutor" plugin specifically designed to *teach* Vim motions/commands using AI. However, several community members noted that AI tools are great for learning how to code, and even developers with three decades of experience use AI daily to explain things. This particular new tech is "particularly well suited for learning 'to code', as it removes barriers for getting started on new projects, with unfamiliar tech stacks."

If you're specifically looking for an AI-powered Vim *tutor* (to learn Vim keybindings and commands interactively with AI guidance), you might consider using one of the chat-based plugins like **vim-ai** or **avante.nvim** and asking the AI to guide you through Vim exercises, or using Neovim's built-in `:Tutor` command alongside an AI assistant.

Here's a summary of the most relevant Neovim AI plugins for asking questions about Vim commands and getting AI help, based on the latest information from 2024–2025:

---

## Top Neovim AI Plugins (2024–2025)

### 1. **avante.nvim**
It looks like a Vibe Coding Agent CLI but is completely Neovim underneath, so you can use your muscle-memory Vim operations and those rich and mature Neovim plugins on it. By leveraging ACP it has all capabilities of Claude Code / Gemini-CLI / Codex. It has a Zen Mode and interactive chat features for asking questions about code, commands, and more.

### 2. **vim-ai**
This plugin adds Artificial Intelligence (AI) capabilities to your Vim and Neovim. You can generate code, edit text, or have an interactive conversation with GPT models, all powered by OpenAI's API. This makes it straightforward to ask questions about Vim commands directly in your editor.

### 3. **gp.nvim (GPT Prompt)**
The goal is to extend Neovim with the power of GPT models in a simple unobtrusive extensible way, trying to keep things as native as possible — reusing and integrating well with the natural features of (Neo)vim. Non-interactive command mode is available for common repetitive tasks implementable as simple hooks (explain something in a popup window, write unit tests for selected code into a new buffer, finish selected code based on comments in it, etc.). The following LLM providers are currently supported besides OpenAI: Ollama for local/offline open-source models.

### 4. **sidekick.nvim** (by folke)
sidekick.nvim adds: Next Edit Suggestions (NES): Multi-line refactorings and context-aware edits across your file; AI CLI Integration: Built-in terminal for Claude, Gemini, and other AI tools. It includes built-in prompts like "Explain {this}" and "Can you fix {this}?" for asking questions contextually.

### 5. **CopilotChat.nvim**
Users report using Neovim with copilot.lua and CopilotChat.nvim; copilot.lua is a Lua port of an "official" copilot plugin, and CopilotChat.nvim and other assistant-like plugins are community efforts to provide Cursor-like features in Neovim. The copilot inline plugin is very smooth and massively helpful.

### 6. **NeoCodeium**
It offers the possibility to complete only word/line of the suggestion, with no debounce by default, allowing suggestions to appear while typing. This is more of an AI code completion plugin rather than a Q&A tool.

### 7. **Comprehensive List**
There's a large ecosystem including gen.nvim (for generating text using LLMs with customizable prompts, 🌟 1514 stars), supermaven-nvim, copilot-cmp, gp.nvim (🌟 1306 stars supporting Claude, Ollama, and OpenAI), and vim-ai (🌟 1132 stars supporting Claude and OpenAI).

---

### Best Picks for Asking Questions About Vim Commands
If your primary goal is to **ask AI questions about Vim/Neovim commands** interactively:

- **vim-ai** and **gp.nvim** are excellent choices since they offer interactive chat sessions where you can ask freeform questions.
- **avante.nvim** is great if you want a more "Cursor-like" integrated experience.
- **sidekick.nvim** is a newer option from the prolific plugin author folke, with built-in contextual prompts.

The GitHub repository at [ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins](https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins) maintains a comprehensive, up-to-date list of all Neovim AI plugins if you want to explore further options.

Here are the most relevant Neovim plugins that integrate AI/LLM capabilities for explaining vim commands and code:

## Top Neovim LLM Plugins

### 1. **CodeCompanion.nvim** (by olimorris)
It supports LLMs from Anthropic, Copilot, GitHub Models, DeepSeek, Gemini, Mistral AI, Novita, Ollama, OpenAI, Azure OpenAI, HuggingFace and xAI, as well as Agent Client Protocol for coding with agents like Claude Code, Codex, and more. It features inline transformations, code creation, refactoring, variables, slash commands, tools, workflows, and a "built-in prompt library for common tasks like advice on LSP errors and code explanations."
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/olimorris/codecompanion.nvim

### 2. **llm.nvim** (by Kurama622)
A large language model (LLM) plugin that allows you to interact with LLM in Neovim. It supports any LLM, such as GPT, GLM, Kimi, DeepSeek, Gemini, Qwen or local LLMs (such as ollama), and allows you to define your own AI tools, with different tools able to use different models. Users can chat, translate text, and explain code using customizable LLMs and tools for efficient task completion.
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/Kurama622/llm.nvim

### 3. **llm-nvim** (by julwrites)
A Neovim plugin for integrating with Simon Willison's llm CLI tool. It has a dedicated `:LLMExplain` command: Type `:LLMExplain` and press Enter — the LLM will explain the code in the current buffer. You can also visually select a block of code, type `:LLMWithSelection Refactor this code for clarity` and press Enter, and the selected code and your prompt will be sent to the LLM.
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/julwrites/llm-nvim

### 4. **GPTModels.nvim** (by Aaronik)
GPTModels is a multi model, window-based LLM AI plugin for Neovim, with an emphasis on stability and clean code. The code window (`:GPTModelsCode`) is great for iterating on a selection of code — you have three panes: the left pane holds code you're working on, the right pane code-only responses from the LLMs, and then you have an input for your prompt.
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/Aaronik/GPTModels.nvim

### 5. **llm.nvim** (by Hugging Face)
This plugin supports "ghost-text" code completion, à la Copilot. Requests for code generation are made via an HTTP request. You can use the Hugging Face Inference API or your own HTTP endpoint. llm.nvim can interface with multiple backends hosting models.
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/huggingface/llm.nvim

### 6. **Curated List of AI Plugins**
There's also a plugin that lets you "describe what to do in Neovim and have OpenAI figure out a command to accomplish" it — which is specifically aimed at translating natural language descriptions into Vim commands.
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins (comprehensive list)

### General Insights

If Neovim is your editor of choice, integrating large language model (LLM) plugins can drastically boost your workflow. These tools bring AI code generation, documentation, refactoring, and smart suggestions right into your editor.

AI plugins using LLMs are transforming Neovim into a cutting-edge tool for developers. These latest AI-powered plugins and integrations enhance coding efficiency, streamline workflows, and elevate the development experience.

If you're specifically looking for a plugin that **explains Vim commands** (not just code), the plugin referenced in the curated list that lets you describe tasks in natural language and have OpenAI figure out the Vim command would be most relevant. For general code explanation and AI chat within Neovim, **CodeCompanion.nvim** and **Kurama622/llm.nvim** are the most feature-rich options.

Here's what I found about **wtf.nvim**:

## wtf.nvim — Diagnostic Debugging in Neovim

**wtf.nvim** is a Neovim plugin to help you work out what the fudge that diagnostic means and how to fix it! It was created by **piersolenski** and is hosted on GitHub.

### What It Does

wtf.nvim provides faster and more efficient ways of working with the buffer line's diagnostic messages using AI and web search. It works with any language that has LSP support in Neovim.

### How It Works

wtf.nvim works by sending the line's diagnostic messages along with contextual information (such as the offending code, file type and severity level) to various sources you can configure.

### Key Features

1. **AI-Powered Explanations**: Use the power of AI to provide you with explanations and solutions for how to fix diagnostics, custom tailored to the code responsible for them.

2. **AI-Powered Fixes**: Instead of explaining the issue, it will attempt to fix it. Additional instructions can be specified, such as `WtfFix using camel casing`.

3. **Web Search Integration**: Why spend time copying and pasting, or worse yet, typing out diagnostic messages, when you can open a search for them in Google, Stack Overflow and more, directly from Neovim?

4. **Multiple AI Providers**: Support for Anthropic, Copilot, DeepSeek, Gemini, Grok, Ollama and OpenAI.

5. **Provider Switching**: Allows you to pick a different provider other than the one initially set in your config without restarting Vim.

### Commands

- **`Wtf`** — Sends the code and diagnostic messages for a line or visual range to the provider. Additional instructions can also be specified, which might be useful if you want to offer extra context, such as `Wtf I'm using Node.js`.
- **`WtfFix`** — Attempts to automatically fix the diagnostic issue using AI.
- **`WtfSearch`** — Uses a search engine (defaults to the one in the setup or Google if not provided) to search for the first diagnostic.

### Default Keybindings (from example config)

| Key | Description |
|---|---|
| `<leader>wd` | Debug diagnostic with AI |
| `<leader>wf` | Fix diagnostic with AI |
| `<leader>ws` | Search diagnostic with Google |
| `<leader>wp` | Pick provider |
| `<leader>wh` | Populate quickfix list with previous chat history |
| `<leader>wg` | Grep previous chat history with Telescope |

### Dependencies

The plugin requires:
- `nvim-lua/plenary.nvim`
- `MunifTanjim/nui.nvim`
- Optionally: `nvim-telescope/telescope.nvim`, `folke/snacks.nvim`, or `ibhagwan/fzf-lua` (for grep history)

In essence, wtf.nvim bridges the gap between cryptic LSP diagnostic messages and actionable understanding — letting you leverage AI or web search to quickly understand and resolve errors without leaving your editor.

Here's what I found:

## **describe-command.nvim**

The top result is **[describe-command.nvim](https://github.com/oflisback/describe-command.nvim)** by `oflisback`.

Instead of trying to remember all the Vim and Neovim commands available, this plugin lets the user describe a command and then have an OpenAI model come up with a command to execute or a few suggestions to choose from.

This is exactly the plugin matching your query — it allows you to describe what you want to do in natural language, and it leverages OpenAI to generate the appropriate Vim/Neovim command for you.

It is also listed in the community-curated list of Neovim AI plugins as a tool that lets you "describe what to do in neovim and have OpenAI figure out a command to accomplish it."

You can find the plugin and its installation/configuration instructions on its GitHub page: [https://github.com/oflisback/describe-command.nvim](https://github.com/oflisback/describe-command.nvim)

Based on my search results, I was unable to find specific Neovim plugins with the exact names **explain.nvim**, **tutor.nvim**, **mentor.nvim**, **guide.nvim**, or **assist.nvim** as standalone, dedicated plugins. However, here's what I did find that's related:

---

## Related Findings

### Built-in Tutor
Neovim has a built-in `:Tutor` command you can use to learn your first Vim commands. This is a 30-minute tutorial that teaches the most basic Vim functionality hands-on. Vim and Neovim come with built-in documentation and tutorials — you can run `:Tutor` at any time to pop up a neat tutorial.

### Neovim's Tutor Plugin (built-in)
Neovim has a built-in `pi_tutor` plugin documented in its official help pages. The source for this can be found in the [neovim/neovim repository](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/plugin/tutor.vim).

### dependency-assist.nvim
**dependency-assist.nvim** (by akinsho) is a neovim plugin written in Lua, which is designed to help you find out which dependencies are up to date and add new ones to your dependency file. These commands are buffer specific and only added within a supported file — for now this is any dart file or a pubspec.yaml.

### ai-assistant.nvim
**ai-assistant.nvim** (by IwasakiYuuki) is a Neovim plugin that allows ChatGPT to be used from within the editor. It can receive and display ChatGPT's responses in a dedicated chat history buffer, which allows you to review past conversations.

### AI "Explain" Functionality
While there's no standalone `explain.nvim`, some AI plugins include explain features:
- **piersolenski/wtf.nvim** — AI powered diagnostic debugging, helps explain complex errors and offers custom tailored solutions.
- **mrf/gemini-code-assist.nvim** includes Smart Actions such as fix, simplify, document, explain, and generate tests.

### Learning/Guide Resources (not plugins per se)
- The **learn-nvim** guide (by ofirgall) explains that Neovim is a fork of vim which integrates an LSP client and Lua API for configuration and plugin creation, and that the community created a diverse plugin ecosystem which feels designed right, robust, scalable and replaceable.

---

**Summary:** No plugins named exactly `explain.nvim`, `tutor.nvim` (as a third-party plugin), `mentor.nvim`, `guide.nvim`, or `assist.nvim` appear to exist as notable standalone Neovim plugins. The closest matches are Neovim's **built-in `:Tutor`** feature, **ai-assistant.nvim**, **dependency-assist.nvim**, and AI plugins like **wtf.nvim** and **gemini-code-assist.nvim** that include "explain" functionality.

Based on my search results, here's what I found for the specific terms you searched for:

## Results for "helpgpt", "vimgpt", "vim-help-ai", "nvim-help-ai" Neovim Plugins

### 1. VimGPT (by nsbradford)
**GitHub:** https://github.com/nsbradford/VimGPT

This is an experimental LLM agent/toolkit with direct Vim access, using neovim/pynvim. It is intended for use either as a sub-agent for efficient file editing, or as its own agent runtime.

Key details:
- VimGPT tends to be quite fast, but does consume a lot of requests/tokens because each command is its own request. There is an option for allowing multiple commands per request, but this tends to degrade agent performance.
- So far, only gpt-4 seems capable of using this properly. Even GPT-4 can sometimes get confused and submit files that are clearly wrong, and sometimes can enter endless loops of using the wrong commands.
- You'll need to install neovim; if you're on MacOS you can simply `brew install neovim`. Then install from PyPI.

### 2. VimGPT (AI chatbot on yeschat.ai)
**Website:** https://www.yeschat.ai/gpts-ZxX6Wc4a-VimGPT

VimGPT is an AI-powered tool designed to enhance Neovim users' experience by providing support for plugin development, configuration, and scripting with Vimscript and Lua. VimGPT is a specialized AI assistant designed to provide expert guidance on Vim and NeoVim. It caters to both beginners and advanced users, offering tailored advice based on the user's experience level. For newcomers, VimGPT simplifies complex concepts, while for seasoned users, it dives into advanced features and technical nuances.

Note: This is a ChatGPT-4o-powered web chatbot, not a Neovim plugin itself.

---

### No Results Found For:
- **"helpgpt"** — No Neovim plugin by this name was found in the search results.
- **"vim-help-ai"** — No Neovim plugin by this name was found.
- **"nvim-help-ai"** — No Neovim plugin by this name was found.

### Related AI Neovim Plugins (from search results)
If you're looking for AI-powered Neovim help/assistance plugins, these popular alternatives appeared in the results:

- **ChatGPT.nvim** ([jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim](https://github.com/jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim)) — ChatGPT Neovim Plugin: Effortless Natural Language Generation with OpenAI's ChatGPT API.
- **gp.nvim** ([Robitx/gp.nvim](https://github.com/Robitx/gp.nvim)) — The goal is to extend Neovim with the power of GPT models in a simple unobtrusive extensible way, trying to keep things as native as possible.
- **vim-ai** ([madox2/vim-ai](https://github.com/madox2/vim-ai)) — AI-powered code assistant for Vim. OpenAI and ChatGPT plugin for Vim and Neovim.
- **Neural** ([dense-analysis/neural](https://github.com/dense-analysis/neural)) — A Neovim/Vim coding agent plugin. Neural integrates various machine learning tools so you can let AI write code for you in Neovim/Vim.
- A comprehensive list of Neovim AI plugins is maintained at [ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins](https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins), which was last updated on "2026-02-25".

Here's a summary of the most relevant Neovim/Vim AI plugins found across the search results:

---

## Neovim AI Plugins Overview

### 1. **vim-ai** (madox2/vim-ai)
This plugin adds Artificial Intelligence (AI) capabilities to your Vim and Neovim. You can generate code, edit text, or have an interactive conversation with GPT models, all powered by OpenAI's API. In case you would like to experiment with Gemini, Claude or other models running as a service or locally, you can use any OpenAI compatible proxy. Commands include `:AI`, `:AIEdit`, `:AIChat`, and more.

### 2. **avante.nvim** (yetone/avante.nvim)
avante.nvim is a Neovim plugin designed to emulate the behaviour of the Cursor AI IDE. It provides users with AI-driven code suggestions and the ability to apply these recommendations directly to their source files with minimal effort. Use the `:AvanteAsk` command to query the AI about the code. It also features a "Zen Mode" that looks like a Vibe Coding Agent CLI but is completely Neovim underneath. So you can use your muscle-memory Vim operations and those rich and mature Neovim plugins on it. At the same time, by leveraging ACP it has all capabilities of claude code / gemini-cli / codex!

### 3. **sidekick.nvim** (folke/sidekick.nvim)
sidekick.nvim is your Neovim AI sidekick that integrates Copilot LSP's "Next Edit Suggestions" with a built-in terminal for any AI CLI. Review and apply diffs, chat with AI assistants, and streamline your coding, without leaving your editor. It includes built-in prompts for explaining, fixing, optimizing, reviewing code, and writing tests.

### 4. **askCode** (e3oroush/askCode)
AskCode is a Neovim plugin that helps developers explore and understand codebases by connecting to CLI-based AI assistants like gemini-cli and amazonq. It acts as your in-editor guide, letting you ask context-aware questions about selected code. Features include built-in use cases like explaining code, finding bugs, or suggesting optimizations. Code replacement: Select code and ask AI to modify it directly in your buffer (add docstrings, fix bugs, refactor, etc.).

### 5. **NeoAI** (Bryley/neoai.nvim)
NeoAI is a Neovim plugin that brings the power of OpenAI's GPT-4 directly to your editor. It helps you generate code, rewrite text, and even get suggestions in-context with your code. The plugin is built with a user-friendly interface, making it easy to interact with the AI and get the assistance you need.

### 6. **Neural** (dense-analysis/neural)
A Neovim/Vim coding agent plugin. Neural integrates various machine learning tools so you can let AI write code for you in Neovim/Vim, among other helpful things. Use OpenAI's APIs made famous with ChatGPT, in Vim, or other local models. It includes a `:NeuralExplain` command to ask AI to explain selected code.

### 7. **NeoCodeium** (monkoose/neocodeium)
Free AI completion plugin powered by windsurf (formerly codeium). You can chat with AI in the browser with the `:NeoCodeium chat` command. The first time you open it, it requires the server to restart with some chat-specific flags.

### 8. **ai-assistant.nvim** (IwasakiYuuki/ai-assistant.nvim)
This is a Neovim plugin that allows ChatGPT to be used from within the editor. Receive and display ChatGPT's responses in a dedicated chat history buffer. Chat history buffer allows you to review past conversations.

### 9. **Pieces for Neovim**
Unlock the power of AI within Neovim using `:PiecesCopilot`. Get instant coding help, debugging advice, or generate snippets—all in a split view, without ever leaving your editor.

### Comprehensive List
For a full curated list, check out the list of Neovim AI community plugins maintained at **[ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins](https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins)** on GitHub.

---

Here are the search results for **gen.nvim** by David-Kunz. The original query combining gen.nvim with "explain vim" / "how to use vim" / "vim commands" didn't return specific matches for those exact phrases in the context of gen.nvim custom prompts. However, the second search provided detailed information about the plugin and its custom prompt system. Here's a summary:

## gen.nvim — Neovim Plugin for LLM Text Generation

gen.nvim generates text using LLMs with customizable prompts, and requires Ollama with an appropriate model such as llama3.2, mistral, etc.

### Installation & Configuration

You can install it with lazy.nvim and configure custom parameters including the default model, keymaps (quit, retry, accept), host/port for the Ollama service, display mode ("float", "split", "horizontal-split", or "vertical-split"), and options like `show_prompt` and `show_model`.

### Custom Prompts

The plugin comes with built-in prompts and supports creating your own. The built-in prompts include templates for changing text, improving grammar and spelling, improving wording, making text concise, reviewing code, and enhancing code — all using placeholders like `$text`, `$filetype`, and `$input`.

All prompts are defined in `require('gen').prompts`, and you can enhance or modify them. For example, you can add custom prompts like `Elaborate_Text` or `Fix_Code` with specific prompt strings, `replace` behavior, and `extract` patterns. The prompt can be a string or a function, and supports placeholders.

### Usage

You select a block of code that you want to ask about, then run `:Gen`.

### Connecting to Other Endpoints

You can customize the plugin configuration to connect to other endpoints such as OpenAI by changing the model, host, port, and command function.

### No Results for "Explain Vim" Custom Prompts

The search did **not** return any results specifically showing gen.nvim custom prompts designed to "explain vim," "how to use vim," or "vim commands." If you're looking to create such a custom prompt, you could define one like this based on the plugin's prompt system:

```lua
require('gen').prompts['Explain_Vim'] = {
  prompt = "Explain the following vim command or concept in detail:\n$text",
}
```

This would let you select text (e.g., a vim command) and use `:Gen Explain_Vim` to get an LLM-powered explanation.

Here are the top Neovim plugins for piping questions to an LLM API and showing results in a simple, lightweight chat interface:

---

## 1. **sllm.nvim** (by mozanunal / NunoSempere)

A lightweight Neovim wrapper for Simon Willison's `llm` CLI that lets you chat with LLMs, run agentic workflows, and complete code without leaving your editor. It integrates ChatGPT-style LLMs into Neovim for asking questions and keeping multi-file context, and is a highly configurable, async, lua-only plugin.

- Features include interactive chat (sending prompts to any installed LLM backend with streaming replies), context management for files/URLs/diagnostics/shell output, and model & tool selection.
- Simple setup — press `<leader>ss` to start chatting. Defaults use the `<leader>s` prefix.
- GitHub: `mozanunal/sllm.nvim`

---

## 2. **llm.nvim** (by Kurama622)

A large language model plugin that allows you to interact with LLMs in Neovim. It supports any LLM (GPT, GLM, Kimi, DeepSeek, Gemini, Qwen, or local LLMs like Ollama), allows you to define your own AI tools with different models, and can use free models from platforms like Copilot, GitHub models, SiliconFlow, OpenRouter, or Cloudflare.

- Results will be displayed in a flexible window.
- Supports one-time questions with no history retained.
- GitHub: `Kurama622/llm.nvim`

---

## 3. **model.nvim** (by gsuuon)

Use AI models in Neovim for completions or chat. Build prompts programmatically with Lua. Designed for those who want to customize their prompts, experiment with multiple providers, or use local models.

- Prompts go in the setup table and are run by the command `:Model [prompt name]` or `:M [prompt name]`, with tab-completion for available prompts.
- A prompt entry defines how to handle a completion request — it takes in editor input and context, produces the API request data, and defines how to handle the response (e.g., replace the selection or insert at cursor position).
- GitHub: `gsuuon/model.nvim`

---

## 4. **simplegpt.nvim** (by you-n-g)

SimpleGPT is a Vim plugin designed to provide a simple (high transparency based on Jinja) yet flexible way (context-aware based on buffer, visual selection, LSP info, terminal, etc.) to customize your LLM/ChatGPT prompts for your tasks or building chat on nearly all kinds of LLM APIs.

- The author notes: "For a long time, I've been looking for a simple way to chat in VIM with any LLM—just having a conversation, without pulling in my codebase as context."
- GitHub: `you-n-g/simplegpt.nvim`

---

## 5. **llm.nvim** (by Hugging Face)

llm.nvim is a plugin for all things LLM, using `llm-ls` as a backend. It supports "ghost-text" code completion à la Copilot, where requests for code generation are made via HTTP request. You can use the Hugging Face Inference API or your own HTTP endpoint.

- GitHub: `huggingface/llm.nvim`

---

### Summary

For the **simplest and most lightweight** "pipe a question → get a result" experience, **sllm.nvim** and **model.nvim** stand out. sllm.nvim wraps the `llm` CLI for minimal setup, while model.nvim gives you fine-grained Lua-based prompt building. If you want a more full-featured chat with multiple model support and a flexible UI, **Kurama622/llm.nvim** is a strong choice.

Here are the results for your search on Neovim LLM/AI plugins for help and documentation querying on GitHub:

---

## Neovim LLM/AI Plugins

### 1. **Kurama622/llm.nvim**
A large language model (LLM) plugin for Neovim that provides commands to interact with LLMs like ChatGPT, Copilot, ChatGLM, Kimi, DeepSeek, OpenRouter, and local LLMs. It supports any LLM such as GPT, GLM, Kimi, DeepSeek, Gemini, Qwen, or local LLMs (such as Ollama), allows you to define your own AI tools with different tools able to use different models, and lets you use free models from platforms like Copilot, GitHub models, SiliconFlow, OpenRouter, Cloudflare, and others.
- **GitHub:** https://github.com/Kurama622/llm.nvim

### 2. **huggingface/llm.nvim**
llm.nvim is a plugin for all things LLM, and it uses llm-ls as a backend. This plugin supports "ghost-text" code completion, à la Copilot, where requests for code generation are made via an HTTP request. You can use the Hugging Face Inference API or your own HTTP endpoint.
- **GitHub:** https://github.com/huggingface/llm.nvim

### 3. **gsuuon/model.nvim**
Use AI models in Neovim for completions or chat. Build prompts programmatically with Lua. Designed for those who want to customize their prompts, experiment with multiple providers, or use local models.
- **GitHub:** https://github.com/gsuuon/model.nvim

### 4. **olimorris/codecompanion.nvim**
Code with LLMs and Agents via the in-built adapters, the community adapters, or by building your own, with support for LLMs from Anthropic, Copilot, GitHub Models, DeepSeek, Gemini, Mistral AI, Novita, Ollama, OpenAI, Azure OpenAI, HuggingFace, and xAI. It also supports Agent Client Protocol for coding with agents like Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI, and more.
- **GitHub:** https://github.com/olimorris/codecompanion.nvim

### 5. **Aaronik/GPTModels.nvim**
GPTModels is a multi-model, window-based LLM AI plugin for Neovim, with an emphasis on stability and clean code. The code window (`:GPTModelsCode`) is great for iterating on a selection of code, with three panes — the left pane holds code you're working on, the right pane code-only responses from the LLMs, and an input for your prompt.
- **GitHub:** https://github.com/Aaronik/GPTModels.nvim

### 6. **blob42/codegpt-ng.nvim**
Codegpt-ng is a minimalistic Neovim plugin designed for efficient, command-line-driven workflows. Built with vimway principles in mind, it supports OpenAI and Ollama APIs seamlessly, enabling powerful code assistance through intuitive cmdline-mode interactions. It includes commands like `question`, `debug`, `doc`, `opt`, `tests`, and `chat`.
- **GitHub:** https://github.com/blob42/codegpt-ng.nvim

### 7. **julwrites/llm-nvim**
A Neovim plugin for integrating with Simon Willison's llm CLI tool. You can type `:LLM Write a short poem about Neovim` and press Enter, and a new buffer will open with the LLM's response. It also supports commands like `:LLMExplain` and `:LLMWithSelection`.
- **GitHub (via neovimcraft):** https://neovimcraft.com/plugin/julwrites/llm-nvim/

### 8. **ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins** (Curated List)
This is a list of Neovim AI plugins, auto-generated and last updated on "2026-02-25". It is a comprehensive directory of AI/LLM-related Neovim plugins.
- **GitHub:** https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins

Here's a summary of what I found regarding using AI to learn Vim/Neovim from within the editor:

## Using AI to Learn Vim from Within Neovim

The exact phrases "ask AI about vim," "learn vim with AI," or "AI vim tutor" from Reddit didn't return direct matches, but there's a rich ecosystem of related content:

### The Core Idea: AI as a Vim Tutor

A Medium article by Andrej Kuročenko captures the concept perfectly. In previous attempts at learning Vim, the cycle was always the same: hitting friction, opening a browser, searching Stack Overflow, finding an answer, forgetting it two hours later, and repeating — the cognitive overhead killed momentum. This time, the author just asked the AI things like "How do I delete everything inside these parentheses?" and got immediate answers. The difference isn't just speed — it's that the AI explains *why* commands work, helping the patterns stick.

### AI Plugins for Neovim That Enable This

Several plugins let you chat with AI directly inside Neovim:

1. **vim-ai** (`madox2/vim-ai`): This plugin adds AI capabilities to Vim and Neovim — you can generate code, edit text, or have an interactive conversation with GPT models, all powered by OpenAI's API.

2. **avante.nvim** (`yetone/avante.nvim`): A Neovim plugin designed to emulate the behaviour of the Cursor AI IDE, providing users with AI-driven code suggestions and the ability to apply recommendations directly to source files.

3. **sidekick.nvim** (`folke/sidekick.nvim`): It integrates Copilot LSP's "Next Edit Suggestions" with a built-in terminal for any AI CLI — review and apply diffs, chat with AI assistants, and streamline coding without leaving the editor.

4. **codecompanion.nvim** (`olimorris/codecompanion.nvim`): Branded as "AI Coding, Vim Style."

5. **opencode.nvim** (`nickjvandyke/opencode.nvim`): Integrates the opencode AI assistant with Neovim to streamline editor-aware research, reviews, and requests.

### The Broader Ecosystem

Neovim now has over 100 AI-related plugins. A comprehensive list is maintained at [ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins](https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins) on GitHub.

### Community Discussion (Lobsters)

There's an active debate about AI + Neovim. One user noted they've been using Neovim for seven years (and Vim for 15), have written multiple plugins, and can type fast — and AI still makes them more productive. Another argued that skill is not a relevant factor when assessing the use of AI tools.

### AI + Neovim Talk (NeovimConf 2024)

Josh Medeski gave a talk on this topic: He discussed how AI plugins using LLMs are transforming Neovim into a cutting-edge tool, exploring the latest AI-powered plugins that enhance coding efficiency and streamline workflows — whether you're a seasoned Neovim user or new to the editor.

---

If you're specifically looking for Reddit threads on this topic, the exact phrases from your query didn't match any Reddit posts in the search results. You might want to try browsing r/neovim directly with broader terms like "AI assistant" or "ChatGPT plugin."

7. "neovim plugin ask question" "neovim chatbot"

9. GitHub search for repos with "neovim" + "help" + "AI" or "LLM"

11. Look for plugins that enhance or replace :help with AI-powered explanations
12. "nvim-help-ai" "vim-help-ai" "neovim-tutor-ai"

Here are the search results for `site:github.com oflisback/describe-command.nvim`:

## [oflisback/describe-command.nvim](https://github.com/oflisback/describe-command.nvim)

**describe-command.nvim** is a Neovim plugin that can be installed using the Lazy package manager. It depends on `nvim-lua/plenary.nvim` and `nvim-telescope/telescope.nvim`, and requires an OpenAI API key provided via the `OPENAI_API_KEY` environment variable.

### Configuration

The default model is `gpt-4o-mini-2024-07-18`, and the model must support structured output.

### Commands

- **`:DescribeCommandExecute`** — This command directly executes the command that best matches the given description.
- **`:DescribeCommandSuggest`** — This command shows a list of suggestions that match the given description.
- For both commands, if no description is given, the user will be prompted for one.

### Community

Contributions, bug reports and suggestions are very welcome.

The plugin also appears in curated lists of Neovim AI plugins, such as a Vim/Neovim AI plugins list on GitHub Gist and the [ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins](https://github.com/ColinKennedy/neovim-ai-plugins) repository.

Seamlessly chat with Claude, get code completion, and use AI assistance directly within Neovim's interface.","url":"https://github.com/IntoTheNull/claude.nvim"},{"title":"Lua - Neovim docs","url":"https://neovim.io/doc/user/lua"},{"title":"GitHub - Flemma-Dev/flemma.nvim: Flemma turns Neovim into a first-class AI workspace.","url":"https://github.com/Flemma-Dev/flemma.nvim"}]

Here are the search results for your query about Neovim Lua functions using curl/plenary with Anthropic/Claude for vim help and question-asking scripts:

## Results Summary

### 1. **claude-code.nvim** (by greggh)
This plugin uses `plenary.nvim` as a dependency for seamless integration between Claude Code AI assistant and Neovim. Claude Code by Anthropic — this plugin was entirely built using Claude Code. You can toggle it with commands like `:ClaudeCode` or from Lua with `vim.cmd[[ClaudeCode]]`, and map it to a key.

### 2. **avante.nvim** (Cursor-like AI in Neovim)
avante.nvim is currently the bleeding-edge plugin trying to replicate the Cursor AI experience entirely within Neovim. It can be configured with Claude as the provider using the Anthropic API endpoint, and depends on `nvim-lua/plenary.nvim` among others. With Avante, you can visually select lines and ask the AI to rewrite them, generating a "diff" view allowing you to accept or reject changes line-by-line using standard vim motions.

### 3. **plenary.nvim curl module**
Plenary describes itself as "full; complete; entire; absolute; unqualified" — "All the lua functions I don't want to write twice." The `plenary/curl.lua` module provides HTTP request capabilities used by many Neovim plugins.

### 4. **curl.nvim** (by oysandvik94)
curl.nvim depends on `nvim-lua/plenary.nvim` and provides commands like `:CurlOpen`. In the left buffer, you can paste or write curl commands, and by pressing Enter, the command will execute, and the output will be shown and formatted in the rightmost buffer.

### 5. **parrot.nvim** (by frankroeder)
Parrot.nvim supports Anthropic with a unified provider system, configuring the endpoint at `https://api.anthropic.com/v1/messages` with proper headers including the `x-api-key` and `anthropic-version`. With `user_input_ui = "native"`, it uses `vim.ui.input` as a slim input interface for asking questions. It also supports custom provider-specific curl parameters like `--insecure`, `--max-time`, and `--proxy`.

### 6. **claude.nvim** (by IntoTheNull)
A Neovim plugin that integrates with Anthropic's Claude AI model directly in your editor, providing AI-powered assistance for your coding workflows. Features include interactive chat interface, code-specific interface, visual selection support, and direct code application.

### 7. **Neovim Lua Documentation**
The Lua 5.1 script engine is builtin and always available. Nvim includes a "standard library" for Lua. The Nvim help pages are generated from source using the tree-sitter-vimdoc parser.

### 8. **flemma.nvim**
Streaming is handled by spawning curl with Server-Sent Events enabled. Flemma works without arguments — `require("flemma").setup({})` uses sensible defaults (Anthropic provider, thinking = "high", prompt caching enabled). You stay in Neovim the whole time, with full visibility into every step. Flemma is not trying to replace dedicated agents like Claude Code or Codex, but it gives you an agent that speaks your language — Vim buffers, not a separate terminal.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's a summary of what I found about customizing system prompts for **CodeCompanion.nvim** and **gp.nvim** in Neovim, including how you could set up a "Vim expert" or "Neovim expert" type custom prompt:

---

## CodeCompanion.nvim — Custom System Prompts

The default system prompt in CodeCompanion has been carefully curated to deliver terse and professional responses that relate to development and Neovim. It is sent with every request in the chat buffer.

The built-in system prompt identifies the AI as "CodeCompanion" working within the Neovim text editor, and it can answer general programming questions, explain code in a Neovim buffer, review selected code, generate unit tests, propose fixes, scaffold code, find relevant code, propose fixes for test failures, and answer questions about Neovim.

### Overriding the System Prompt

You can replace the system prompt entirely with a simple string in your setup configuration, or alternatively, the system prompt can be a function. For example:

```lua
require("codecompanion").setup({
  interactions = {
    chat = {
      opts = {
        system_prompt = "My new system prompt",
      },
    },
  },
})
```

The opts parameter contains several pieces of information related to the chat, which you can use to build the system prompt. This includes language, adapter, date, nvim_version, os, default_system_prompt, cwd, and project_root context fields.

### Custom Prompt Library

You can create custom prompt library entries with specific system roles — for example, setting a system prompt like "You are an expert programmer who excels at explaining code clearly and concisely." You could easily change this to "You are a Neovim expert" or "You are a Vim tutor" for your specific use case.

Markdown prompts (new in v18.0.0) provide a cleaner, more maintainable way to define prompts with support for external Lua files for dynamic content. For complex prompts with multiple messages or dynamic content, markdown files are significantly easier to maintain than Lua tables.

You can store markdown prompts in custom directories:

```lua
require("codecompanion").setup({
  prompt_library = {
    markdown = {
      dirs = {
        vim.fn.getcwd() .. "/.prompts",
        "~/.dotfiles/.config/prompts",
      },
    },
  },
})
```

You can also set the system prompt as a function which can receive the current chat buffer's adapter as a parameter, giving you the option of setting system prompts that are LLM or model specific.

### Tools System Prompt

CodeCompanion also ships with a separate system prompt when tools are used in the chat buffer, which identifies the AI as "a highly sophisticated automated coding agent with expert-level knowledge across many different programming languages and frameworks."

---

## gp.nvim — Custom System Prompts & Agents

The goal of gp.nvim is to extend Neovim with the power of GPT models in a simple unobtrusive extensible way, trying to keep things as native as possible.

### Agent System Prompts

In gp.nvim, the system prompt is configured per-agent, and the plugin renders it via `agent.system_prompt`. You can define custom agents with their own system prompts (e.g., a "Vim Expert" agent) through the configuration.

### Per-Repository Custom Instructions

By calling `:GpContext` you can make a `.gp.md` markdown file in the root of a repository. Commands such as `:GpRewrite`, `:GpAppend` etc. will respect instructions provided in this file (works better with gpt4, gpt 3.5 doesn't always listen to system commands).

For example, you could include instructions like: "Use C++17", "Use Testify library when writing Go tests", or "Use Early return/Guard Clauses pattern to avoid excessive nesting."

You could similarly add a `.gp.md` file with instructions like "You are a Neovim expert. Always provide answers in the context of Neovim configuration and Lua scripting."

### Supported Providers

gp.nvim supports multiple LLM providers beyond OpenAI, including Ollama for local/offline models, GitHub Copilot, Perplexity.ai, Anthropic Claude, and Google Gemini.

---

## Also Relevant: DocsBot Neovim Expert Prompt

There is also a DocsBot "Neovim Configuration Expert" AI prompt designed as a system prompt for ChatGPT, Gemini, and Claude chatbots. While not specific to CodeCompanion or gp.nvim, it demonstrates the concept of a dedicated "Neovim expert" system prompt that could be adapted for use in either plugin.

---

### Summary

Both plugins offer flexible ways to inject custom system prompts. To create a "Vim expert" or "Neovim expert" persona:

- **CodeCompanion**: Override `interactions.chat.opts.system_prompt` with your custom expert prompt, or create a prompt library entry with a `role = "system"` message.
- **gp.nvim**: Define a custom agent with a tailored `system_prompt`, or use a `.gp.md` file per repository for project-specific instructions.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Research Neovim plugins that help users quickly ask questions about Neovim usage itself (not code generation, not coding assistants). The user wants to be inside Neovim and quickly ask things like:
- "How do I delete a word in Neovim?"
- "How do I use macros?"
- "What does ctrl-w do?"
- "How do I search and replace?"
- "How do I use registers?"

This is about learning/querying Neovim itself, not about writing code with AI help.

Search with these varied terms and angles:
1. "neovim AI help" "ask AI about vim"
2. "neovim plugin explain vim commands"
3. "neovim plugin LLM help documentation"
4. "vim AI tutor plugin"
5. "neovim :help AI" "smart help neovim"
6. "wtf.nvim" and similar error/explanation plugins
7. "neovim plugin ask question" "neovim chatbot"
8. "helpgpt" "vimgpt" "vim AI"
9. GitHub search for repos with "neovim" + "help" + "AI" or "LLM"
10. "neovim plugin natural language" "vim natural language commands"
11. Look for plugins that enhance or replace :help with AI-powered explanations
12. "nvim-help-ai" "vim-help-ai" "neovim-tutor-ai"
13. Any plugin that feeds :help docs to an LLM
14. Reddit/HackerNews discussions about "asking AI about vim from within vim"
15. "explain.nvim" "tutor.nvim" "mentor.nvim" "guide.nvim" "assist.nvim"

For EACH plugin found, report:
- Name and GitHub URL
- What it actually does (one line)
- Does it support Claude/Anthropic?
- Is it actively maintained (last commit date)?
- How simple is the interaction? (keymap → answer flow)

Also check if there are any lightweight single-file plugins or even vim commands/scripts that just pipe a question to an API and show the result. Sometimes the simplest solution is a 20-line Lua function, not a full plugin.

Do NOT limit to just "popular" plugins. Include niche, small, single-purpose tools.

Here's what I found about **simplegpt.nvim** by you-n-g:

## Overview

🤏SimpleGPT is a Vim plugin designed to provide a simple (high transparency based on Jinja) yet flexible way (context-aware based on buffer, visual selection, LSP info, terminal etc.) to customize your LLM/ChatGPT prompts for your tasks (building chat or finishing tasks by replacing them with diff comparison, appending, SEARCH/REPLACE etc.) or building chat on nearly all kinds of LLM APIs.

## Key Features

The plugin's efforts are organized into several core areas:

1. **Prompt Templates**: Create your own prompt templates using a Jinja template engine.

2. **Context-aware Question Building**: Construct questions based on the template and the current context, followed by multi-round chat instruction.

3. **Flexible Response Presenting**: Present the response in the most convenient way (options like diff, popup, replace, append).

4. **Tools Gallery**: A tools gallery is provided for basic usage, which also serves as examples for further customization.

## Template Engine

SimpleGPT uses a Jinja-like template engine (jinja-engine.nvim) to power its template system, with variable interpolation that lets you access registers using `{{register_name}}` syntax. The template engine provides familiar Jinja-style syntax while being fully integrated with Neovim.

## Response Actions

After receiving a response, you can integrate the output into your workflow:

- **Append**: Use the Append action (e.g., `<C-a>` key) to add the response to your original buffer.
- **Replace**: Use the Replace action (e.g., `<C-r>` key) to substitute the selected text, current line, or entire file with the response.
- **Yank**: Use the Yank action (e.g., `<C-y>` key) to copy the response to the clipboard.
- **Search and Replace**: Use the Search and Replace action (e.g., `<m-r>` key) to apply automated modifications via SEARCH/REPLACE blocks.

## Chat Feature

It only provides the core feature to chat in an existing buffer. The chat will be organized by emoji like 👤(user), 🤖(AI), 💻(system), and only one customizable shortcut, which is `<LocalLeader>gc` (to trigger chat completion or stop the chat completion stream). You can edit your conversation like a normal buffer and continue chat completion freely.

It supports all kinds of LLMs, including reasoning models. Its backend is based on yetone/avante.nvim, which supports a wide range of LLMs.

## Motivation

The author notes: "For a long time, I've been looking for a simple way to chat in VIM with any LLM—just having a conversation, without pulling in my codebase as context." While pure Vim-powered chat plugins like jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim and robitx/gp.nvim are excellent, they do not support reasoning models. SimpleGPT aims to solve this problem.

## Use Cases

Beyond coding, the plugin supports tasks like: article writing, reading, notetaking, summarizing, and translating.

You can find the project on GitHub at: [https://github.com/you-n-g/simplegpt.nvim](https://github.com/you-n-g/simplegpt.nvim)


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's what I found about **parrot.nvim**:

## parrot.nvim 🦜 — Stochastic Parrots for Neovim

parrot.nvim offers a seamless out-of-the-box experience, providing tight integration of current LLM APIs into your Neovim workflows, with a focus solely on text generation. A substantial part of the code is based on an early fork of the brilliant work by Tibor Schmidt's gp.nvim.

**GitHub Repository:** [frankroeder/parrot.nvim](https://github.com/frankroeder/parrot.nvim)

### Key Features

The plugin supports persistent conversations stored as markdown files within Neovim's standard path or a user-defined location, custom hooks for inline text editing based on user instructions and chats with predefined system prompts, and a unified provider system supporting any OpenAI-compatible API including: OpenAI API, **Anthropic API**, Google Gemini API, xAI API, local and offline serving via Ollama, and any custom OpenAI-compatible endpoint. It also supports Perplexity.ai API, Mistral API, Groq API, DeepSeek API, GitHub Models, and NVIDIA API. It offers flexible API credential management from environment variables, bash commands, and password manager CLIs with lazy evaluation.

- It allows custom agent definitions, flexible API credential support, and repository-specific instructions with a `.parrot.md` file.
- It does not have autocompletion or hidden requests in the background to analyze files.
- The user is always under full control of what will be sent to the LLM API endpoint, hence this plugin fully excludes the whole notion of agents provided by tools such as codex, claude-code, and the gemini-cli.

### Chat & Command Usage

- Chats in parrot.nvim are essentially standard Markdown buffers. You can open a chat using `:PrtChatNew` for a fresh chat buffer (or `:PrtChatToggle` to toggle the last one), then type your prompt after the user prefix, and trigger the LLM with `<C-g><C-g>` in insert mode or the `:PrtChatRespond` command.
- The LLM streams its response directly into the buffer at your cursor position. You can press `<C-g>s` to stop the generation at any time.
- Command mode allows you to interact with LLMs directly on your code without leaving your current buffer.

### Repository Stats & Last Update

The repository was created about 2 years ago, has 552 commits and 23 authors. Its topics include `anthropic`, `claude-3-5-sonnet`, `gemini`, `neovim`, `ollama`, `openai`, and more.

### Philosophy

This plugin is intended for people who actually know what they are doing and people who care for privacy and transparency. It's described as "a lean, keyboard-first assistant that stores chats as Markdown and supports multiple providers, including Anthropic—great for quick prompts, refactors, and sticky notes alongside code."

Highly configurable, async, lua-only plugin.","url":"https://neovimcraft.com/plugin/mozanunal/sllm.nvim/"},{"title":"sllm.nvim/doc/configure.md at main · mozanunal/sllm.nvim","url":"https://github.com/mozanunal/sllm.nvim/blob/main/doc/configure.md"},{"title":"Show HN: Sllm.nvim – Integrate Simon’s LLM cli into Neovim (500 LOC Lua) | Hacker News","url":"https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=44050267"},{"title":"sllm.nvim/doc/hooks.md at main · mozanunal/sllm.nvim","url":"https://github.com/mozanunal/sllm.nvim/blob/main/doc/hooks.md"},{"title":"sllm.nvim/README.md at main · mozanunal/sllm.nvim","url":"https://github.com/mozanunal/sllm.nvim/blob/main/README.md"}]

Here's what I found about **sllm.nvim**:

## Overview

sllm.nvim is a Neovim plugin that integrates Simon Willison's `llm` CLI directly into your editor. You can chat with large language models, stream responses in a scratch buffer, manage context files, switch models or tool integrations on the fly, and control everything asynchronously without leaving Neovim.

## Lightweight & Minimal Design

sllm.nvim is a thin wrapper around the `llm` CLI (~500 lines of Lua). It delegates all heavy lifting (API calls, model management, conversation history, and tool integration) to Simon Willison's robust, battle-tested, and community-maintained tool. This keeps sllm.nvim lightweight, transparent, and easy to maintain.

## Key Features

- **Customizable Agentic Modes:** Modes are just YAML files, tools are just Python functions.
- **Explicit Context Control:** Add or reset files, URLs, shell command outputs, selections, diagnostics, installed LLM tools, or on-the-fly Python functions in the context so the model can reference your code, web content, command results, or issues.
- **Native `llm` Integration:** Uses llm's templates, tools, and history. Async streaming — Responses stream in real-time with loading indicator.
- **Extensible Ecosystem:** By building on `llm`, this plugin instantly inherits its vast and growing plugin ecosystem. Want to use OpenRouter's 300+ models? Just run `llm install llm-openrouter`.

## Templates / Modes

sllm.nvim uses `llm` templates as "modes" that configure the LLM's behavior. Templates define system prompts and optionally provide Python functions as tools. Templates are YAML files stored in llm's templates directory. The plugin ships with modes including:
- General-purpose chat mode, best for conversations, questions, and getting help with code.
- Code review mode with read-only file access. The LLM can explore your codebase but cannot make changes.
- Full agentic mode with read and write access. The LLM can execute commands, read files, and make changes.
- Inline completion mode, used internally by `<leader><Tab>` / `complete_code()` for code completion at the cursor.

## Philosophy

sllm.nvim isn't designed to be a replacement for feature-rich plugins like CodeCompanion.nvim or Copilot.nvim, but a focused alternative built on a distinct philosophy. sllm.nvim believes in a co-pilot model where you are always in control.

## Repositories

- **Original:** [mozanunal/sllm.nvim](https://github.com/mozanunal/sllm.nvim)
- **Fork:** [NunoSempere/sllm.nvim](https://github.com/NunoSempere/sllm.nvim) — sllm.nvim itself is created and maintained by mozanunal, focusing on integrating these tools smoothly into Neovim. Licensed under Apache 2.0.

Here are the search results for your query about Neovim plugins related to vim motions/keybindings with AI-powered interactive teaching:

## Results Overview

The search didn't surface a specific AI-powered Neovim plugin that interactively teaches vim motions, but it returned several relevant resources for learning vim motions interactively and related Neovim motion plugins:

### Interactive Learning Tools

1. **VimGym** (vimgym.dev) — VimGym offers interactive Vim exercises that let you practice motions in your browser. Start with basic navigation (hjkl), then progress to word motions, editing commands, and advanced techniques. Whether you use Vim, Neovim, or VS Code with Vim keybindings, the exercises work everywhere, and practice motions that transfer across all editors.

2. **Vim Adventures & Vim Hero** — Tools like Vim Adventures (a gamified vim experience) and Vim Hero (learn vim with interactive examples, challenges, and games) are recommended for easing into vim motions before fully committing.

### Neovim Motion Plugins

3. **Hop.nvim** (GitHub) — Hop is a complete from-scratch rewrite of EasyMotion, a famous plugin to enhance the native motions of Vim. It provides a modern, Neovim-native approach to quick navigation.

4. **Spider-like motions** — There are plugins that let you "use the w, e, b motions like a spider" and "move by subwords and skip insignificant punctuation."

### Learning Approaches & Guides

5. **"Learn (Neo)Vim in 10 months"** (Medium, by Igor Vokoun) — The author argues that learning vim motions by using vim/neovim directly isn't ideal because you're learning two things at once and will get frustrated. Instead, they recommend using your preferred editor/IDE and installing a vim motions plugin first.

6. **"A Noob's Neovim Journey"** (codeminer42.com, Nov 2025) — Vim can be separated into three parts: vim motions, the vim editor, and vim plugins. Vim motions consist of modes and commands that help developers navigate and edit code more efficiently, without taking their hands off the keyboard.

7. **"Why You Should Finally Learn Vim (Yes, Even in 2025)"** (Medium) — You can easily get started with Vim motions inside your code editor with plugins such as VSCodeVim. Learning just a few basic commands can give you 80% of the benefits, including speed, efficiency, and ergonomics.

8. **Neovim 101 — Motion** (alpha2phi, Medium) — This article explains that vim motion is a command that moves the cursor and explores plugins that can improve the user experience using Vim motions, as part of the Neovim 101 series.

9. **Neovim Keybindings** (catalins.tech, Nov 2024) — This post showcases a list of useful Neovim keybindings for various modes, navigation, buffer management, file operations, and AI capabilities.

### Key Takeaway

While there doesn't appear to be a single dedicated **AI-powered Neovim plugin** that interactively teaches vim motions within the editor itself, the ecosystem offers a combination of browser-based interactive trainers (like VimGym, Vim Adventures), motion-enhancing plugins (like Hop.nvim), and comprehensive learning guides. If you're specifically looking for an AI-integrated teaching plugin for Neovim, this may be a niche that hasn't been fully filled yet — would you like me to search more specifically for that?

Here are the results for your search on **codegpt-ng.nvim by blob42**:

## codegpt-ng.nvim (blob42)

**codegpt-ng.nvim** is a minimalist command-based AI plugin for Neovim that interacts with LLM backends like Ollama and OpenAI with a powerful template system.

### Installation

It can be installed using Packer with the dependencies `MunifTanjim/nui.nvim` and `nvim-lua/plenary.nvim`, and configured via `require("codegpt").setup({...})`.

### Commands & Usage

- The main way to call codegpt is through the top-level command `:Chat`, optionally followed by a `{command}` and `{arguments}`.
- The behavior is different depending on whether text is selected and/or arguments are passed.
- `:Chat!` makes the popup window persistent when the cursor leaves.
- For any command, if the command accepts a visual selection it will also accept cmdline-ranges. A visual selection with `:Chat` triggers the completion command with a text selection.

### Configuration

- The `{commands}` config table can be used to override the builtin default commands or to define new commands.
- You can specify model parameters like `max_tokens`, `temperature`, and `append_string` to customize behavior.
- See `lua/codegpt/config.lua` for the full config specification.

### Features

- The output is displayed using one of the builtin callback types, with the most common being `text_popup` and `code_popup` which open a popup/window and display the LLM response.
- The response is streamed in real time unless `config.ui.stream_output` is set to `False`.
- You can call `:lua codegpt.select_model()` to interactively choose a model via UI.

### License

Copyright (c) 2025 - Chakib Benziane. The project is licensed under the terms of the AGPL3 license.

### Community

The plugin is listed in the awesome-neovim collection as a "minimalist command based AI coding with a powerful template system" that supports Ollama, OpenAI and more.

You can find the full repository at: [https://github.com/blob42/codegpt-ng.nvim](https://github.com/blob42/codegpt-ng.nvim)

Here are the search results for **jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim**:

## jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim — Overview

ChatGPT.nvim is a Neovim plugin that allows you to effortlessly utilize the OpenAI ChatGPT API, empowering you to generate natural language responses from OpenAI's ChatGPT directly within the editor in response to your inquiries.

### Key Features

- **Interactive Q&A:** Engage in interactive question-and-answer sessions with the powerful GPT model (ChatGPT) using an intuitive interface.
- **Persona-based Conversations:** Explore various perspectives and have conversations with different personas by selecting prompts from Awesome ChatGPT Prompts.
- **Code Editing Assistance:** Enhance your coding experience with an interactive editing window powered by the GPT model, offering instructions tailored for coding tasks.
- **Code Completion:** Enjoy the convenience of code completion similar to GitHub Copilot, leveraging the capabilities of the GPT model to suggest code snippets and completions based on context and programming patterns.

### Commands — "Explain", "Ask", and More

- The plugin supports interactive roleplay — by using the "chatgpt ask as" command, you can ask ChatGPT to roleplay as different profiles, such as a Linux terminal, JavaScript console, SQL terminal, or even a full-stack developer.
- You can provide instructions to ChatGPT to edit your code using the "chatgpt edit with instructions" command, which opens an interactive window where you can specify instructions for modifying your code.
- Tests can be created with the `:ChatGPTRun add_tests` command.
- The plugin also offers code autocompletion capabilities similar to Copilot — by using the "chatgpt run complete code" command, ChatGPT will suggest code completions based on the context.

### Maintenance / Activity Status

The search results did not return specific information about the **last commit date** or whether the plugin is actively maintained **in 2025**. However, there are some signals:

- Some newer plugins like SimpleGPT note that "pure Vim-powered chat plugins like jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim and robitx/gp.nvim are excellent, they do not support reasoning models," suggesting there may be feature gaps or stagnation.
- The plugin is still listed in the awesome-neovim collection as "jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim - Effortless Natural Language Generation with OpenAI's ChatGPT API."
- The plugin is described as "designed to be simple to use and easy to install" and "extensible, you can add custom prompts."

For the most up-to-date commit activity, I'd recommend checking the GitHub repository directly at [github.com/jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim](https://github.com/jackMort/ChatGPT.nvim) — the search results didn't surface a definitive last commit date or a 2025-specific maintenance status.
